   (A)   There is established in and for the city a Department of Public Works.
   (B)   The Department shall consist of a Director of Public Works and other
officers and personnel as determined from time to time by Council.
   (C)   The Directory of Public Works is also referred to as the
Superintendent of Public Works in these codified ordinances.
(Ord. 2006-02-0008O, passed 2-28-2006)
§ 32.116 ASSISTANT DIRECTOR AND STREET SUPERINTENDENT.
   (A)   There is established the office of Assistant Director of Public Works
and Street Superintendent. These positions shall be appointed by the Mayor with
the approval of Council. The term of the appointment shall begin at the start
of the fiscal year, May 1, and expire on April 30 the final date of the fiscal
year.
   (B)   (1)   The Director, Assistant Director or Street Superintendent may be
removed during the term of the appointment by the Mayor, with the approval of
Council.
      (2)   The grounds for removal may include job performance, alternate
administrative procedures, departmental efficiency or otherwise. The Assistant
Superintendent so removed shall have the right to a hearing before Council
regarding the basis for removal.
   (C)   Subject to the direction of the Director of Public Works, the
Assistant Director and Street Superintendent shall be responsible for the
supervision of the Department of Public Works, as specified within their
respective job descriptions.
(Ord. 2006-02-0008O, passed 2-28-2006)
§ 32.117 DISQUALIFICATION OF APPLICANTS FOR CERTAIN OFFENSES.
   (A)   All applicants for positions in the Department of Public Works of the
City of Oak Forest are required to possess or obtain an Illinois commercial
driver’s license and shall be eligible and qualified to operate city motor
vehicles. Therefore, to protect public health, safety and welfare, no person
shall be eligible to apply and test for, accept, or be employed in any position
within the Department of Public Works, that is subject to the jurisdiction of
the Civil Service Commission, if:
      (1)   The applicant has been convicted of more than two “serious traffic
violation” within three years of the date of application for employment. For
purposes of this section, “a serious traffic violation” is defined as:
         (a)   A violation of section 11-402(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to leaving the scene of an accident involving damage to a vehicle.
ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-402(a);
         (b)   A violation of section 11-403 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to failure to stop and exchange information after a motor vehicle
collision involving property damage only. ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-403;
         (c)   A violation of section 11-502(a) of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating illegal transportation, possession, or carrying of alcoholic liquor
within the passenger area of any vehicle. ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-502(a);
         (d)   A violation of section 6-101 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to operating a motor vehicle without a valid license or permit. ILCS
Ch. 625, Act 5, § 6-101;
         (e)   A violation of Section 11-403 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to failure to stop and exchange information or give aid after a motor
vehicle collision involving personal injury or death. ILCS Ch. 625 Act 5, § 11-
403;
         (f)   A violation related to excessive speeding, involving speeding
over 15 miles per hour over the speed limit;
         (g)   A violation relating to reckless driving;
         (h)   A violation of section 11-707(d) of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to passing in a no passing zone. ILCS Ch. 625 Act 5, § 11-707(d);
         (i)   A violation of section 11-1402(b) of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to limitations on backing upon a controlled access highway. ILCS Ch.
625, Act 5, § 11-1402(b);
         (j)   A violation of section 11-707(b) of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to driving on the left side of a roadway in a non-passing zone. ILCS
Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-707(b);
         (k)   A violation of section 11-1002(e) of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to failure to yield the right-of-way to a pedestrian at an
intersection. ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-1002(e);
         (l)   A violation of section 11-1008 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to failure to yield to a pedestrian on a sidewalk. ILCS Ch. 625, Act
5, § 11-1008;
         (m)   A violation for failure to reduce speed to avoid an accident;
         (n)   A violation for driving too fast for conditions;
         (o)   A violation of Section 11-605 of the Illinois Vehicle Code,
relating to exceeding the speed in a school zone. ILCS Ch. 625, Act 5, § 11-
605;
         (p)   A violation for improper or erratic traffic lane changes, lane
usage and/or center lane usage;
         (q)   A violation for improper passing on the roadway, including,
without limitation, a violation for passing on the wrong side of the road or a
violation for passing on the shoulder, left or right side;
         (r)   A violation for passing a school bus receiving or discharging
passengers or displaying a warning not to pass;
         (s)   A violation of ILCS Ch. 635, Act 5, § 11-710, for following
another vehicle more closely than is reasonable and prudent, having due regard
for the speed of such vehicles and the traffic upon and the condition of the
highway;
         (t)   A violation of section 11-1201, relating to failure to stop for
an approaching railroad train or railroad equipment or signals. ILCS Ch. 625,
Act 5, § 11-1201; or
         (u)   Any other similar violation of a law or local ordinance of any
state relating to motor vehicle traffic control.
      (2)   The applicant’s driver’s license is suspended or revoked at the
time of application for employment.
      (3)   The applicant has been convicted of driving under the influence of
drugs or alcohol, under any state law or local ordinance in the three year
period prior to application for employment.
      (4)   The applicant is unable to obtain an Illinois Commercial Driver’s
License within 90 days of the date of hire.
   (B)   The bases for disqualification provided under this section shall be in
addition to all other bases for disqualification for employment with the city,
under any state or federal law, rules or regulations, or local ordinance, or
Civil Service Commission Rule. Nothing contained in this Section shall be
construed to limit the authority of the Civil Service Commission to disqualify
an applicant from consideration for employment, or discipline an employee up to
and including termination.
   (C)   The provisions of this section shall apply to automatically disqualify
only new applicants for positions of employment within the Department of Public
Works and shall not result in any automatic disqualification of any current
employees in the Department of Public Works.
(Ord. 2015-04-059O, passed 4-12-2016) Penalty, see §
10.99

BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
§ 32.145 ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION; TERMS OF OFFICE.
   There is established in and for the city a Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners consisting of three members who shall be appointed by the Mayor
with the consent of Council and who shall serve respectively for the following
terms: one to serve until the end of the current municipal year, one to serve
until the end of the municipal year next ensuing and the third to serve until
the end of the municipal year second next ensuing. The successor to each member
so appointed shall serve for three years and until his or her respective
successor is appointed and qualified.
(2000 Code, § 2.44.010)
§ 32.146 OATH AND BOND; REQUIREMENTS OF MEMBERS.
   (A)   The members of the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall be
considered officers of the municipality and shall file an oath and a fidelity
bond in such manner as may be required by Council.
   (B)   No person holding a lucrative office under the United States, this
state or any political subdivision thereof or a municipality shall be a member
of the Board or the Secretary thereof. The acceptance of any lucrative office
by a member of the Board shall be treated as a resignation of his or her office
as a member of the Board or the Secretary thereof. No person shall be appointed
a member of the Board who is related, either by blood or marriage up to the
degree of first cousin, to any elected official or the municipality. Not more
than two members of the Board shall belong to the same political party existing
in the municipality at the time of appointments and as defined in ILCS Ch. 10,
Act 5, § 10-2, the Election Code. If only one or no political party exists in
the municipality at the time of the appointments, then state or national
political party affiliations shall be considered in making such appointments.
Party affiliation shall be determined by affidavit of the person appointed as a
member of the Board.
(2000 Code, § 2.44.020)
§ 32.147 APPOINTMENTS TO POLICE AND FIRE DEPARTMENTS.
   (A)   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall appoint all officers
and members of the Fire Department and the Police Department, except the Chief
of Police and the Fire Chief, which appointments may be made by the Mayor with
the consent of Council.
   (B)   All appointments made by the Board shall be made from the rank next
below that to which the appointment is made, other than that of the lowest
rank.
(2000 Code, § 2.44.030)
§ 32.148 RULES; POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall make the rules and
appointments and removals as set forth in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 10-2.1-1 et
seq.
(2000 Code, § 2.44.040) (Ord. 2418, (part), passed --1999; Ord. 2417, (part),
passed --1999)
§ 32.149 SECRETARY.
   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may employ a Secretary or
designate one of its own members to act as Secretary. The Secretary shall keep
the minutes of the Board’s proceedings, shall be custodian of all papers
pertaining to the business of the Board, shall keep a record of all
examinations held and shall perform other duties as the Board prescribes.
(2000 Code, § 2.44.050)
BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF POLICE PENSION FUND
§ 32.160 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is established in and for the city a Board of Trustees of the Police
Pension Fund.
(2000 Code, § 2.46.010)
§ 32.161 COMPOSITION.
   The Board of Trustees of the Police Pension Fund shall consist of five
members, two of whom shall be appointed by the Mayor, two of whom shall be
elected from the regular Police Department and one of whom shall be a
beneficiary under the Police Pension Fund Act, as established by statute.
(2000 Code, § 2.46.020)
§ 32.162 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   Of the two members of the Board of Trustees of the police pension fund
appointed by the Mayor, one shall serve for one year beginning May 14, 1963,
and the other shall serve for two years beginning May 14, 1963. The successors
to the trustees shall serve for two years each or until such time as their
successors are appointed and qualified.
   (B)   (1)   The third and fourth members of the Board shall be elected from
the regular Police Department by the active members thereof as provided by
statute.
      (2)   The fifth member shall be elected from the beneficiaries under the
Police Pension Fund Act.
   (C)   Of these three members, all shall serve for two years beginning on May
14, 1963, and all shall be elected as provided by statute.
(2000 Code, § 2.46.030)
§ 32.163 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Trustees of the police pension fund shall exercise and have all
the powers and duties delegated to it by statute.
(2000 Code, § 2.46.040)
BOARD OF LOCAL IMPROVEMENTS
§ 32.175 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   (A)   There is established in and for the city a Board of Local
Improvements, which shall consist of the Mayor and seven members of Council.
   (B)   Those members shall be appointed by the Mayor.
(2000 Code, § 2.50.010)
§ 32.176 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Local Improvements shall have the powers and perform the duties
assigned to it by statute or ordinance.
(2000 Code, § 2.50.020)
§ 32.177 MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Board of Local Improvements shall meet upon the call of the Mayor
or any two members, provided that at least 24 hours’ notice of the call is
given each member.
   (B)   However, a meeting may be held when all members are present without
notice.
(2000 Code, § 2.50.030)
§ 32.178 SECRETARY.
   The Secretary of the Board of Local Improvements shall be appointed from one
of the members of the Board.
(2000 Code, § 2.50.040)
§ 32.179 EXPENDITURES.
   The Board of Local Improvements, without Council approval, may expend
budgeted sums not to exceed $2,500 per line item, or $2,500 for any particular
project proposed before the Board.
(2000 Code, § 2.50.050)
EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM BOARD
§ 32.190 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The city establishes an Emergency Telephone System Board.
(2000 Code, § 2.52.010)
§ 32.191 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Emergency Telephone System Board shall be to coordinate
and supervise the planning and implement action and upgrading of the enhanced
9-1-1 system.
(2000 Code, § 2.52.020)
§ 32.192 COMPOSITION.
   The Emergency Telephone System Board shall consist of the Police Chief, Fire
Chief, Public Works Director, Emergency Management Director, Network
Administrator and the Radio Room Supervisor.
(2000 Code, § 2.52.030) (Am. Ord. 2017-01- 0630O, passed 1-10-2017)
§ 32.193 (RESERVED).
§ 32.194 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Emergency Telephone System Board shall have the following powers and
duties:
   (A)   Planning a 9-1-1 system;
   (B)   Coordinating and supervising the implementation, upgrading and
maintenance of the system, including the establishment of equipment
specifications and coding systems;
   (C)   Receiving moneys from the surcharge imposed under ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5,
§ 15.3, and from any other source, for deposit into the emergency telephone
system fund;
   (D)   Authorizing all disbursements from the fund; and
   (E)   Hiring, on a temporary basis, any staff necessary for the
implementation or upgrade of the system.
(2000 Code, § 2.52.050)
§ 32.195 EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM FUND.
   (A)   All moneys received by the Emergency Telephone System Board, pursuant
to a surcharge imposed under Ordinances 1600, passed January 10, 1989; 1631,
passed May 9, 1989; and 2192, passed July 16, 1996, shall be deposited into an
emergency telephone system fund.
   (B)   The Oak Forest City Treasurer shall be custodian of the fund. All
interest accruing on the fund shall remain in the fund.
   (C)   No expenditures may be made from the fund except upon the direction of
the Board by resolution passed by a majority of all members of the Board.
   (D)   Expenditures may be made only to pay for the costs associated with the
following:
      (1)   The design of the emergency telephone system;
      (2)   The coding of an initial master street address guide data base, and
update and maintenance thereof;
      (3)   The repayment of any moneys advanced for the implementation of the
system;
      (4)   The charges for automatic number identification and automatic
location identification equipment, and maintenance, replacement and update
thereof;
      (5)   The nonrecurring charges related to installation of the emergency
telephone system and the ongoing network charges; and
      (6)   Other products and services necessary for the implementation,
upgrade and maintenance of the system. However, the costs shall not include
personnel or facilities, nor shall the costs include equipment which is not
directly associated with the 9-1-1 emergency telephone system.
(2000 Code, § 2.52.060)
EMERGENCY TELEPHONE SYSTEM ADVISORY BOARD
§ 32.210 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The city establishes an Emergency Telephone System Advisory Board.
(2000 Code, § 2.54.010)
§ 32.211 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of the Emergency Telephone System Advisory Board shall be to
provide input, advice and information to the Emergency Telephone System Board
as to the implementation and upgrading of the 9-1-1 system.
(2000 Code, § 2.54.020)
§ 32.212 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENTS.
   (A)   The Emergency Telephone System Advisory Board shall consist of five
members who are residents of the city.
   (B)   They shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the City
Council on the basis of their particular fitness for duty on the Board as well
as prior experience.
(2000 Code, § 2.54.030)
§ 32.213 TERMS OF OFFICE; COMPENSATION.
   (A)   The members of the Emergency Telephone System Advisory Board shall be
appointed on an annual basis.
   (B)   All members of the Advisory Board shall serve without compensation but
shall be reimbursed for their actual or necessary expenses.
(2000 Code, § 2.54.040)
§ 32.214 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Emergency Telephone System Advisory Board shall have the following
powers and duties:
   (A)   To render advice to the 9-1-1 Board as to the planning of a 9-1-
1 system;
   (B)   To render advice to the 9-1-1 Board regarding coordinating and
supervising the implementation, upgrading and maintenance of the system,
including the establishment of equipment specifications and coding systems;
   (C)   To render advice regarding receiving moneys from the surcharge imposed
under ILCS, Ch. 65, Act 5, § 15.3 and from any other source, for deposit into
the emergency telephone system fund; and
   (D)   To render other duties as may be delegated by the 9-1-1 Emergency
Telephone System Board, with the approval of the City Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.54.050)
FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD
§ 32.225 ESTABLISHMENT.
   The city does create and establish a Foreign Fire Insurance Board. The Board
shall have the powers, duties and responsibilities provided for in this
subchapter.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.010)
§ 32.226 COMPOSITION.
   The Foreign Fire Insurance Board, hereinafter referred to as the F.F.I.B.,
shall consist of the Fire Chief and four elected members of the Oak Forest Fire
Department and shall include the following officers:
   (A)   President;
   (B)   Vice-president;
   (C)   Secretary; and
   (D)   Treasurer.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.020)
§ 32.227 ELECTION OF OFFICERS; TERMS.
   (A)   The election of officers of the F.F.I.B. shall take place annually
during the final quarter of each calendar year.
   (B)   Any officer elected after the passage of this subchapter shall serve
up to and including December 31, 1991.
   (C)   The terms of each officer thereafter shall be from January 1 through
December 31 of the same calendar year.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.030)
§ 32.228 FIREFIGHTER EMPLOYMENT STATUS REQUIRED.
   The President, Vice President, Secretary and Treasurer of the Board shall be
firefighters in the Oak Forest Fire Department at the time of their election
and during the entire time each may serve as an officer.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.040)
§ 32.229 DUTIES AND POWERS OF OFFICERS.
   (A)   President. The President shall preside at all meetings of the
officers. The President shall have other powers as he or she may be given from
time to time by action of the Oak Forest City Council, consistent with the
Illinois Municipal Code.
   (B)   Vice President. The Vice President shall carry out the duties of the
president during the absence or inability of the president to perform such
duties and shall carry out other functions as are assigned from time to time by
the F.F.I.B. President or the Oak Forest City Council.
   (C)   Secretary. The Secretary shall take minutes of any and all meetings of
the officers. The Secretary shall keep these minutes in a manner identical to
the manner in which City Council minutes are kept. The Secretary shall also
perform any other duties and functions as are assigned from time to time by the
Mayor or the Oak Forest City Council.
   (D)   Treasurer. The Treasurer shall:
      (1)   Have charge and custody of and be responsible for all funds
collected by the city from the foreign fire insurance company fees as described
in ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 11-10-1;
      (2)   Deposit all moneys in the name of the City of Oak Forest Fire
Department in banks, savings and loan associations or other depositories as
shall be designated by the Oak Forest City Council;
      (3)   Invest said funds as are not immediately required in such
securities as the Oak Forest City Council shall specifically or generally
select from time to time;
      (4)   Maintain the financial books and records of the F.F.I.B.;
      (5)   In general, perform all duties incident to the office of Treasurer
and other duties as from time to time may be assigned to him or her by the
F.F.I.B. or the Oak Forest City Council;
      (6)   Give a sufficient bond to the city. This bond shall be approved by
the Mayor, conditioned upon the faithful performance by the Treasurer of his or
her duties under this subchapter and the rules and regulations provided for
herein. The bond shall be paid for from the funds collected from the foreign
fire insurance company fees; and
      (7)   Receive the foreign fire insurance company fees so paid and pay out
the money upon the order of the F.F.I.B. for the maintenance, use and benefit
of the Department.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.050) (Ord. 2418, (part), passed --1999; Ord. 2417, (part),
passed --1999)
§ 32.230 TERMS OF OFFICE OF OFFICERS.
   The President, Vice President, Secretary and Treasurer shall serve for one-
year terms and shall be elected to office by the members of the Oak Forest Fire
Department. The first election for those officers shall take place within 30
days of the passage of the ordinance codified in this subchapter. No officer
shall serve in the same office for more than two consecutive full year terms.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.060)
§ 32.231 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The officers of the F.F.I.B. shall make all needful rules and regulations
with respect to the management of the foreign fire insurance company fees to be
paid to the Treasurer. All rules and regulations promulgated by the F.F.I.B.
must be passed by the affirmative vote of at least three of the four presiding
officers. All rules and regulations promulgated by the F.F.I.B. must be
approved by the Oak Forest City Council in the same manner as a city ordinance
must be passed.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.070)
§ 32.232 PAYMENT OF FUNDS.
   The City Treasurer shall pay the sums received from the insurance company
specified in ILCS Ch.65, Act 5, § 11-10-1 to the Treasurer of the F.F.I.B. of
the city.
(Ord. 2418 (part), 1999; Ord. 2417 (part), 1999)
§ 32.233 BUDGET.
   (A)   Preliminary budget. The F.F.I.B. officers shall approve a preliminary
budget for the expenditure of the foreign fire insurance company fees collected
by March of each year.
   (B)   Final budget.
      (1)   The F.F.I.B. officers shall, by December of each year prior to the
start of each fiscal year, adopt a final budget for the collection and payment
of the foreign fire insurance company fees.
      (2)   The final budget shall be approved by the City Council in the same
fashion as any other regular city ordinance.
   (C)   Budget amendments. The Oak Forest F.F.I.B. budget referred to in
division (A) above may be amended at any time by a majority vote of the
F.F.I.B. and a majority vote of the City Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.090)
§ 32.234 ANNUAL AUDIT.
   (A)   The F.F.I.B. shall provide to the Oak Forest City Council an annual
audit of the financial affairs of the Fire Department to be made by a certified
public accountant at the end of each fiscal year in accordance with generally
accepted auditing principals.
   (B)   The annual report shall be delivered to the Mayor, City Treasurer and
City Administrator. The audit shall be paid for from funds collected from the
foreign fire insurance company fees.
(2000 Code, § 2.56.100)
CITIZENS ADVISORY COMMISSION
§ 32.245 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is established a Citizens Advisory Commission, which shall be known as
the Oak Forest Citizens Advisory Commission.
(Ord. 2006-11-0067O, passed 11-14-2006)
§ 32.246 MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   The Oak Forest Citizens Advisory Commission shall be composed of nine
commissioners and one ex-officio alderman to serve as liaison between the
commissioners and Council. All commissioners shall be appointed by the Mayor
with the advice and consent of the Council. The ex-officio alderman shall be
appointed by the Mayor. Commissioners shall serve until retirement or
replacement.
   (B)   The commissioners shall have the right to select their own chairperson
from the members already appointed by the Mayor.
   (C)   Vacancies on the Commission shall be filled in the same manner in
which the original appointments are required to be made.
(Ord. 2012-07-0390O, passed 7-24-2012)
§ 32.247 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Oak Forest Citizens Advisory Commission shall have the following
powers and duties:
      (1)   To coordinate projects and assignments given to it by the Mayor and
Council and perform duties at the direction of the Mayor and Council;
      (2)   To provide recommendations to the Mayor and Council pertaining to
the effectiveness and format of city-sponsored community events;
      (3)   To provide input and recommendations regarding programs or efforts
to increase citizen involvement in the community;
      (4)   To recommend strategies to establish and maintain effective
communications; and
      (5)   To establish meeting dates and times as well as rules of order for
the operation of the Commission.
   (B)   Nothing in these powers and duties shall in any way be construed to
usurp the duties of the Mayor or Council, which are nondelegable.
(Ord. 2006-11-0067O, passed 11-14-2006)
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION
§ 32.260 COMPOSITION.
   Pursuant to ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-1-1, the Mayor shall forthwith appoint
three Civil Service Commissioners, who shall be known as the Civil Service
Commission of the city.

passed --1999)
§ 32.261 CLASSIFICATION OF EMPLOYEES.
   Pursuant to ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-1-3, the Civil Service Commission shall
classify all of the offices and places of employment in the city, except those
offices and places excluded by ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-1-17 and except for
police officers and firefighters, who are subject to the jurisdiction of the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.

   Pursuant to ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-1-5 and ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 10-1-6,

purposes of the Commission.

passed --1999)
§ 32.263 ORGANIZATION.
   The Civil Service Commission shall be organized and shall function in
accordance with ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 10-1-1 through 10-1-48, as amended.
(2000 Code, § 2.66.040) (Ord. 2418, (part), passed --1999; Ord. 2417, (part),

§ 32.264 EXPIRATION OF CANDIDATE LISTS.
   All entry level candidate lists shall expire one year following the final
approval and posting of any list by the Civil Service Commission.
(2000 Code, § 2.66.050) (Ord. 2758, § 2, passed --2003)
CONSUMER PROTECTION COMMISSION
§ 32.275 ESTABLISHMENT AND COMPOSITION; TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   There is established in and for the city a Commission of Consumer
Protection, the chairperson of which shall be entitled the Commissioner of
Consumer Protection.
   (B)   The Commission shall consist of ten members. All Commissioners will be
appointed by the Mayor of the City of Oak Forest with the advice and consent of
the City Council. The Oak Forest Consumer Protection Commission shall have the
right to select its own chairman from the members already appointed by the
Mayor.
   (C)   Vacancies on the Commission shall be filled in the same manner in
which the original appointments are required to be made.
   (D)   The members of the Commission shall represent a cross-section of
consumer interests and shall not include local businessmen and business women
who own and/or manage a city business that might be the subject of a Commission
investigation or regulation.
(2000 Code, § 2.68.010) (Ord. 2012-09-0400O, passed 9-25-2012)
§ 32.276 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Commission and consumer protection shall:
   (A)   Enforce all laws in relation to weights and measures and all laws in
relation to consumer protection;
   (B)   Receive and investigate complaints from all persons affected by
potential or actual violations of any of the provisions of this subchapter, or
initiate its own investigation of frauds and unfair dealings against such
persons;
   (C)   Issue subpoenas to compel the attendance of witnesses and the
production of documents, papers, books, records and other evidence in any
matter over which this subchapter applies; administer oaths or affirmations to
any person whose testimony is required; interrogate witnesses; inspect
premises; require written answers to questionnaires; and require periodic
written reports and the filing of statements;
   (D)   Issue cease and desist orders with respect to consumer practices
declared to be unlawful by the Commission;
   (E)   Report to the appropriate law enforcement officer any information
concerning a violation of any consumer protection law, which reports shall be
at the discretion of the Commission;
   (F)   Represent the interest of consumers before administrative and
regulatory agencies and legislative groups;
   (G)   Assist, advise and cooperate with local, state and federal agencies
and officials to protect and promote the interest of the consumers of the city;
   (H)   Assist, develop and conduct programs of consumer education and
information through publications and other materials prepared for distribution
to the consumers of the city;
   (I)   Undertake activities to encourage local business and industry to
maintain high standards of honesty, fair business practices and public
responsibility in the production, promotion and sale of consumer merchandise
and services and in the extension of credit; and
   (J)   Exercise and perform such other functions, powers and duties as may be
deemed necessary or appropriate to protect and promote the welfare of the
consumers of the city.
(2000 Code, § 2.68.020)
§ 32.277 EXISTING RIGHTS AND REMEDIES.
   No existing right or remedy shall be lost, impaired or affected by reason of
the adoption of the ordinance codified in this subchapter.
(2000 Code, § 2.68.030)
CRIME PREVENTION COMMISSION
§ 32.290 RECITALS.
   The City Council finds that all the recitals contained in the preamble to
the ordinance codified in this subchapter are full, true and correct, and
incorporates them into this subchapter by this reference.
(2000 Code, § 2.70.010) (Ord. 2220, § 1, passed --1997)
§ 32.291 CREATION OF THE CRIME PREVENTION COMMISSION.
   (A)   There is created the Crime Prevention Commission of Oak Forest.
   (B)   The Commission volunteers will be comprised of 13 members, with one
serving as Commission Chair, who shall be elected by a majority of the members.
   (C)   Eligible persons for appointment shall be submitted to the Mayor and
their appointment shall be by the Mayor with the approval of the City Council.
   (D)   The term of appointment shall begin at the start of the fiscal year
and end with the final date of that year.
   (E)   The Mayor, Chief of Police, and the Executive Director of the Chamber
of Commerce shall be named as ex-officio members of this Commission.
(2000 Code, § 2.70.020) (Ord. 2220, § 2, passed --1997; Ord. 2745, § 1, passed
--2003; Am. Ord. 2009-09-0257O, passed 9-8-2009)
§ 32.292 OBJECTIVE.
   (A)   The objective of the Crime Prevention Commission shall be to help
develop and promote crime prevention planning and programming activities that
benefit citizens and businesses within Oak Forest.
   (B)   The Oak Forest Police Department’s crime prevention officer will serve
as liaison to the commission and will assist the Commission in the development
of its plans and programs.
   (C)   The Crime Prevention Commission will be utilized to help the city
achieve its stated goals for crime prevention and disseminate information of
the public to keep it better informed about crime prevention.
   (D)   Through the establishment of plans and programs initiated in a
coordinated effort with the Police Department, the Crime Prevention Commission
will help effectuate more proactive measures to prevent crime and protect the
public and its property.
(2000 Code, § 2.70.030) (Ord. 2220, § 3, passed --1997)
§ 32.293 QUALIFICATIONS.
   The qualifications for appointment as a member to the Oak Forest Crime
Prevention Commission shall include the following.
   (A)   All Commission members must be at least 21 years of age.
   (B)   The Chief of Police shall screen all persons and review their
qualifications.
   (C)   All appointees must profess an interest in and a basic understanding
of the philosophy and practice of crime prevention, and be willing to
participate in training opportunities that may be available.
(2000 Code, § 2.70.040) (Ord. 2220, § 4, passed --1997)
§ 32.294 DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Crime Prevention Commission, working in cooperation with the Oak Forest
Police Department, shall have the following duties and responsibilities to
effectuate crime prevention in our community:
   (A)   Act as a liaison to the community, as well as to other entities
relative to law enforcement;
   (B)   Develop and improve crime prevention plans and programs;
   (C)   Promote public awareness of crime prevention activities;
   (D)   Obtain and organize relevant law enforcement information;
   (E)   Assist in the dissemination of materials and hand-outs; and
   (F)   Maintain media relations on crime prevention and law enforcement
activities in Oak Forest.
(2000 Code, § 2.70.050) (Ord. 2220, § 5, passed --1997)
FINANCE COMMISSION
§ 32.320 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   There is established in and for the city a Finance Commission, to be
composed of the Mayor and aldermen, the City Treasurer and a Budget Officer.
(Ord. 2006-04-0024O, § 2, passed 4-25-2006)
§ 32.321 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Finance Commission shall:
   (A)   Permit, encourage and establish the use of efficient planning,
budgeting, auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal management
procedures in all municipal departments, commissions and boards;
   (B)   Compile an annual budget;
   (C)   Examine all books and records of all municipal departments,
commissions and boards which relate to moneys received by the municipality and
municipal departments, commissions and boards, and paid out by the municipality
and municipal departments, commissions and boards, debts and accounts
receivable and amounts owed by or to the municipality and municipal
departments, commissions and boards;
   (D)   Obtain such additional information from the municipality and municipal
departments, commissions and boards as may be useful to the Budget Officer for
purposes of compiling a municipal budget, the information to be furnished by
the municipality and municipal departments, commissions and boards in the form
required by the Budget Officer. Any department, commission or board which
refuses to make such information as requested of it available to the Budget
Officer shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any subsequent budget
for the municipality until the municipal department, commission or board
complies in full with the request of the Budget Officer;
   (E)   Establish and maintain such procedures as will ensure that no
expenditures are made by the municipality or municipal departments, commissions
or boards except as authorized by the budget;
   (F)   Compile a budget, such budget to contain estimates of revenue
available to the municipality for the fiscal year for which the budget is
drafted, together with recommended expenditures for the municipality and all
other municipal departments, commissions and boards. Revenue estimates and
expenditure recommendations shall be presented in a manner which is in
conformity with good fiscal management procedures. The budget shall be itemized
in a manner consistent with a chart of accounts as may now or in the future be
approved by the City Treasurer. The budget shall contain actual or estimated
revenue and expenditures for the two years immediately preceding the fiscal
year for which the budget is prepared. So far as is possible, the fiscal date
for the two preceding fiscal years shall be itemized in a manner which is in
conformity with the chart of accounts. Each budget shall show the specific fund
from which each anticipated expenditure shall be made; and
   (G)   Authorize, as necessary, without Council approval, budget adjustments
not to exceed, either positively or negatively, $2,500 per line item.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.020)
§ 32.322 ANNUAL BUDGET IN LIEU OF APPROPRIATION ORDINANCE.
   Passage of the annual budget by Council shall be in lieu of passage of the
appropriation ordinance.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.030)
§ 32.323 ADOPTION OF ANNUAL BUDGET.
   The annual budget shall be adopted by Council before the beginning of the
fiscal year to which it applies.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.040)
§ 32.324 CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT, REPAIR OR REPLACEMENT FUND.
   In the preparation by the Finance Commission of the annual budget, one-half
of one percent of equalized assessed value of property subject to taxation by
the city may be accumulated in a separate fund for the purposes or specific
capital improvements, repairs and/or replacements of specific types of
municipal equipment or other tangible property, both real and personal, which
fund shall be designated as the capital improvement, repair or replacement
fund. Expenditures from the fund shall be budgeted in the fiscal year in which
the capital improvement, repair or replacement will occur. Upon the completion
or abandonment of any object for which the fund was used, or if surplus moneys
remain after the completion or abandonment of any object for which the fund was
inaugurated, then the funds no longer necessary for capital improvement, repair
or replacement shall be transferred into the general corporate fund of the
municipality on the first day of the fiscal year following the abandonment,
completion or discovery of surplus funds.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.050)
§ 32.325 REVISION OF ANNUAL BUDGET.
   (A)   Council may delegate authority to heads of municipal departments,
boards or commissions to delete, add to, change or create subclasses within
object classes budgeted previously to the department, board or commission,
subject to the limitation or requirement for prior approval by the Budget
Officer or the Mayor as Council, upon a two-thirds vote, may establish.
   (B)   By a vote, the annual budget for the municipality may be revised by
deleting, adding to, changing or creating subclasses within object classes and
object classes themselves. No revision of the budget shall be made increasing
the budget if funds are not available to effectuate the purpose of the
revision.
(2000 Code, § 3.80.060)
§ 32.326 MONEYS FOR CONTINGENCIES.
   The annual budget may contain money set aside for contingency purposes, not
to exceed 10% of the total budget (excluding the amount set aside for
contingency purposes), which money may be expended for contingencies upon a
majority vote of Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.070)
§ 32.327 PUBLIC INSPECTION OF BUDGET.
   Council shall make the tentative budget conveniently available to public
inspection for at least ten days prior to the passage of the annual budget.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.080)
§ 32.328 APPLICATION OF STATE STATUTES.
   ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, § 8-2-9.1 through 8-2-9.10 shall apply to all procedures
under this subchapter.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.090) (Ord. 2418, (part), passed --1999; Ord. 2417, (part),
passed --1999)
§ 32.329 MEETINGS.
   The Finance Commission shall meet once every month or at the call of the
Budget Officer with two days’ notice.
(2000 Code, § 2.80.100)
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
§ 32.340 CREATED.
   There is created a Planning and Zoning Commission, which shall consist of
the nine members of the present Planning Commission. The Planning and Zoning
Commission shall be deemed to be the “Board of Appeals,” as described in ILCS
Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 11-13-1 et seq., and the "Plan Commission," as described in
ILCS Ch. 65, Act 5, §§ 11-12-1 et seq.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.010) (Ord. 2272, § 1, passed --1997)
§ 32.341 PURPOSE.
   (A)   It is the purpose and intent of this subchapter to place all of the
responsibilities and powers of the former Zoning Board of Appeals and the
former Planning Commission under the jurisdiction of one commission, to consist
of nine members as provided for in this subchapter, and to be called the
Planning and Zoning Commission of the city.
   (B)   Matters coming before that Commission shall be interpreted and ruled
upon by the Planning and Zoning Commission and in doing so, the Planning and
Zoning Commission shall utilize the standards and procedural requirements
contained in the ordinances of the city as the case may be.
   (C)   It is understood that there may be multiple issues to be decided and
ruled upon at the same hearing and that different voting requirements and/or
standards may be necessary to approve certain actions.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.020) (Ord. 2272, § 11 (part), passed --1997)
§ 32.342 COMPOSITION; APPOINTMENTS.
   (A)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall consist of the present
members of the Planning Commission and any additional appointees necessary to
bring the full membership to nine members.
   (B)   New members shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by the City
Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.030) (Ord. 2272, § 2, passed --1997)
§ 32.343 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The term of each Commission member of the Planning and Zoning Commission
shall be for three years. The Mayor shall fill any vacancies on the Commission,
with confirmation by the City Council, in the same manner those regular
appointments shall be made to the Commission in the future.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.040) (Ord. 2272, § 3, passed --1997)
§ 32.344 CHAIRPERSON.
   The Mayor shall appoint one of the members of the Planning and Zoning
Commission as chairperson and shall hold office until a successor is appointed.
The chairperson or the Mayor may ask another member of the Commission to serve
as acting chairperson in his or her absence.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.050) (Ord. 2272, § 6, passed --1997)
§ 32.345 MEETINGS.
   (A)   Meetings of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be held at the
call of the chairperson and at regular times as the Commission shall determine.
   (B)   All meetings of the Planning and Zoning Commission shall be open to
the public and be in compliance with the Open Meetings Act.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.060) (Ord. 2272, § 12 (part), passed --1997)
§ 32.346 DUTY OF CHAIRPERSON; APPLICATIONS.
   (A)   It shall be the duty of the chairperson to evaluate the application(s)
before the Planning and Zoning Commission and to outline to the applicant or
his or her representative and to the members of the Commission the standards
and requirements which must be met in each application.
   (B)   When necessary and appropriate, motions shall be voted on separately.
The applicant and city shall have the same rights and obligations as if said
action(s) were taken by two separate boards or commissions.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.070) (Ord. 2272, § 11 (part), passed --1997)
§ 32.347 RULES OF PROCEDURE.
   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure
and may require submissions to each record, plats and other information
necessary to make its determinations.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.080) (Ord. 2272, § 13, passed --1997)
§ 32.348 MINUTES OF PROCEEDINGS.
   (A)   The Planning and Zoning Commission shall keep minutes of its
proceedings showing the vote of each member present.
   (B)   Findings of fact shall be included in the minutes of each case when
required and the reasons for granting or denying the application(s) shall be
specified.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.090) (Ord. 2272, § 12 (part), passed --1997)
§ 32.349 REMOVAL FROM OFFICE.
   Members of the Commission may be removed by the City Council for cause after
written charges have been filed and after a public hearing has been held if
demanded by the member so charged.
(2000 Code, § 2.86.100) (Ord. 2272, § 5, passed --1997)
SENIOR CITIZEN COMMISSION
§ 32.360 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is established a Senior Citizen Commission which shall be known as the
Oak Forest Senior Citizen Commission.
(2000 Code, § 2.88.010)
§ 32.361 MEMBERSHIP.
   (A)   Membership in the Commission shall, as nearly as possible, be
representative of interested groups of the community such as church groups,
senior citizen groups, the United Way, park districts, civic clubs, fraternal
organizations, veterans organizations, homeowners, health care organizations,
commerce and educational organizations, the Social Security Administration,
housing, food and recreation organizations, as well as other organizations.
   (B)   The membership of the Commission shall consist of 13 commissioners and
one ex-officio alderman who shall serve as liaison between the commissioners
and Council.
   (C)   All commissioners, as well as the ex-officio alderman, shall be
appointed by the Mayor with the advice and consent of Council. The
commissioners shall have the right to select their own chairperson from the
members already appointed by the Mayor.
   (D)   Vacancies on the Commission shall be filled in the same manner in
which the original appointments are required to be made.
(2000 Code, § 2.88.020) (Am. Ord. 2012-08-0391O, passed 8-28-2012)
§ 32.362 RESERVED.
§ 32.363 POWERS.
   The Senior Citizen Commission shall have the power to:
   (A)   Review and evaluate community senior citizen services and facilities;
   (B)   Maximize the use of present facilities by senior citizens;
   (C)   Recommend rules and regulations concerning the rendering or operation
of services and facilities under its direction or supervision;
   (D)   Coordinate with other organizations as to the social, recreational,
educational, cultural, art and health services, special events, needs and
opportunities for senior citizens;
   (E)   Coordinate the rendering of services and the operation of facilities
with other agencies;
   (F)   Review and evaluate the use of the senior bus and recommend rules and
regulations concerning its operation and services. The Commission shall also be
responsible for recommending a budget, to the City Council, for the senior bus
for each fiscal year; and
   (G)   Perform other acts as may be necessary or proper to carry out the
purposes of this subchapter, consistent with the direction of the Mayor and
Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.88.040) (Ord. 2006-04-0015O, passed 4-25-2006)
YOUTH COMMISSION
§ 32.375 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   There is established in the city a Youth Commission, to be composed of 13
members, one of whom shall serve as chairperson.
(2000 Code, § 2.94.010) (Ord. 2410, § 1, passed --1999)
§ 32.376 APPOINTMENT; TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   The members and the chairperson of the Youth Commission shall be
appointed by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council. Five
youth, ages 13 to 19 years, shall serve for two years, and five youths, ages 13
to 19 years, shall serve for one year. Four adults shall be appointed and shall
serve for two years, and all appointments and appointments to fill vacancies
shall be made in like manner as in the case of the initial commissioners. A
commissioner having been duly appointed shall continue to serve after the
expiration of his or her term until his or her successor has been appointed.
All terms shall expire on April 30 in the final year of the member’s term.
   (B)   If a vacancy occurs in the Youth Commission, it shall be filled by
appointment by the Mayor, with the advice and consent of the City Council, upon
recommendation of the chairperson of the Youth Commission, for the unexpired
term of the Youth Commission seat vacated.
(2000 Code, § 2.94.020) (Ord. 2410, § 2, passed --1999)
§ 32.377 RESIDENCY REQUIREMENT.
   Each member of the Youth Commission shall reside in the City of Oak Forest.
A nonresident may serve as an advisor to the Youth Commission, at the request
of the Youth Commission, and shall be appointed by the Mayor, with the advice
and consent of the City Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.94.030)
§ 32.378 DUTIES.
   (A)   The purpose of the Youth Commission shall be to study the concerns of
the youth of the community, to make recommendations regarding areas of youth
activities to the Mayor and the City Council and to assist in the
implementation of solutions as directed by the Mayor and the City Council. The
Youth Commission shall have the primary responsibility of identifying the goals
and progress needed by the city to provide a positive and meaningful
environment for the healthy growth of its youth. It shall recommend and
implement programs that recognize the age differences of teenage youth, as well
as the need to restrict such programs to certain age groups.
   (B)   The Youth Commission shall recommend to the Mayor and the City Council
such policies, and it shall implement the services and programs, as are
established by the Mayor and City Council.
   (C)   The Youth Commission will mobilize community resources and actively
encourage ongoing programs, or assist in initiating new services or programs,
with several private and public agencies of the city engaged in youth areas,
which support the goals of the Youth Commission as they are defined. The Youth
Commission shall help to educate the citizenry as to present youth services
available and shall assume additional responsibilities in youth-related areas
as the Mayor and City Council from time to time may direct.
   (D)   Initially, and from time to time, as necessary, the Youth Commission
shall plan a forum in order to bring city youth together to express their ideas
and concerns.
(2000 Code, § 2.94.040)
§ 32.379 ELECTION OF SECRETARY; MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Youth Commission shall meet and elect a Secretary from its members
as soon as possible after its establishment.
   (B)   The Youth Commission shall hold meetings as may be necessary, and the
meetings shall be held in City Hall or in some other suitable place.
   (C)   Meetings will be held on a regular basis at the discretion of the
Commission.
(2000 Code, § 2.94.050)
§ 32.380 REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES; ESTABLISHMENT OF LINE ITEM IN CITY’S
BUDGET.
   (A)   Members of the Youth Commission, under the direction of the
chairperson, shall be financially reimbursed for any expenses incurred in the
normal function of their duties.
   (B)   A budget line item shall be established for the Youth Commission, in
each fiscal year budget, and shall be approved by the City Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.94.060)
COMMUNITY POOL COMMISSION
§ 32.382 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is an establishment in the city, the Community Pool Commission to be
composed of four members, one of whom shall serve as Chairperson appointed by
the Mayor and another who will be a representative of the Park District.
(Ord. 2017-11-0667, passed 11-14-2017)
§ 32.383 DUTIES.
   (A)   The purpose of the Community Pool Commission shall be the oversight of
the Oak Forest Community Pool. The Commission will identify goals and progress
needed to provide a safe and enjoyable environment of current facilities and
explore the possibilities of future facilities for the residents of the
community.
   (B)   The Commission shall have the responsibility of tracking and reporting
of the expenses and revenues of the pool, and to work with the City
Administrator to create a budget each year.
   (C)   The Commission shall mobilize community resources, and assist in the
planning of events to support the economic sustainability of the pool.
(Ord. 2017-11-0667, passed 11-14-2017)
§ 32.384 ELECTION OF POSITIONS; MEETINGS.
   (A)   The Community Pool Commission shall meet and elect a Secretary and a
Treasurer from its members as soon as possible after its establishment.
   (B)   Meetings will be held on a regular basis at the discretion of the
Commission.
(Ord. 2017-11-0667, passed 11-14-2017)
§ 32.385 REIMBURSEMENT OF EXPENSES; ESTABLISHMENT OF LINE ITEM IN CITY'S
BUDGET.
   (A)   Members of the Community Pool Commission, under the direction of the
Chairperson, shall be financially reimbursed for any expenses incurred in the
normal function of their duties.
   (B)   A budget line item for revenues and expenses shall be established for
the Community Pool Commission, in each fiscal year budget, and shall be
approved by the City Council.
(Ord. 2017-11-0667, passed 11-14-2017)
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
§ 32.395 ESTABLISHMENT; COMPOSITION.
   (A)   There is established in and for the city the Oak Forest Emergency
Management Agency (“EMA”), to prevent, minimize, repair and alleviate injury or
damage resulting from disaster caused by enemy attack, sabotage or other
hostile action, or from natural or man-made disaster, in accordance with the
Illinois Emergency Services and Disaster Act of 1975.
   (B)   The agency shall consist of the Director and additional members as may
be appointed by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.396 DIRECTOR.
   (A)   The Director of the Emergency Management Agency of the city shall be
appointed by the Mayor by and with the advice and consent of Council on an
annual basis.
   (B)   The Director shall have direct responsibility for the organization,
administration, training, operation and supervision of the agency, subject to
policy direction of the Mayor and Council, as provided by statute.
   (C)   The Director shall represent the city on all matters pertaining to the
Emergency Management Agency. During periods of emergency, as defined by law for
agency purposes, the Director shall coordinate the actions of all the Emergency
Management Agency.
   (D)   The Director is authorized to require the assistance of any and all
able-bodied residents for protection to the public welfare during periods
emergency.
   (E)   The Director is authorized to delegate his or her authority as he or
she deems it.
   (F)   In the event of the absence, resignation or death of the Director or
his or her inability to serve, the Mayor, or any person designated by him or
her, shall be and act as Director until a new appointment is made as provided
in this subchapter.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.397 INTERPRETATION OF CHAPTER.
   (A)   Nothing in this subchapter shall be construed to be a modification of
the executive authority of the Mayor under the various provisions of state law
giving the Mayor certain emergency powers.
   (B)   Rather it is the express intent of this subchapter to assign the
emergency authority that is now existent or subsequently granted or extended by
law to the Emergency Management Agency of the city.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.398 FUNCTIONS AND DUTIES.
   (A)   The Emergency Management Agency of the city shall perform functions
within the city as are prescribed in and by the State Emergency Management
Agency plan and program prepared by the Governor and in and by such orders,
rules and regulations as may be promulgated by the Governor and, in addition
shall perform such duties outside the corporate limits as may be required
pursuant to any mutual aid agreement with any other political subdivision,
municipality or quasi-municipality entered into as provided by the Illinois
Emergency Management Agency Act of 1975.
   (B)   These emergency management and coordinative function include, but are
not limited to, coordination of, but not limited to the following; mutual aid,
ground search and rescue, weather situations (flooding, ice storms, tornado
spotting), maintain the operation of outdoor warning system, radiological and
hazardous material, resource management (preparing and maintaining the
emergency operational plan), communication support, evacuation and relocation,
assist in accident re-construction (rail, air, and vehicle), incident command
center for MABAS divisions, and other situations that require an incident
command center.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
Statutory reference:
   The statutes cited in this section have been repealed. Emergency management
provisions are currently set forth as the Emergency Management Agency Act, ILCS
Ch. 20, Act 3305, §§ 1 et seq.
§ 32.399 MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM.
   (A)   Any member of the City Emergency Management Agency may be designated
as a member of a mobile support team created by the Director of the State
Emergency-Management Agency as provided by law.
   (B)   The leader or mobile support team shall be designated by the Director
of the city “EMA”.
   (C) Any member or a mobile support team who is a city employee or officer
shall, while serving on call to duty by the Governor or the state director,
receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities
incident to the employment or office. Any member who is not a paid officer or
employee of the city shall, while so serving, receive from the state reasonable
compensation as provided by law.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.400 MUTUAL AID AGREEMENTS.
   The Director of the Emergency Management Agency of the city may negotiate
mutual aid agreements with other cities or political subdivisions of the state,
but no agreement shall be effective until it has been approved by the Mayor and
Council and by the State Director of the Emergency Management Agency.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.401 EMERGENCY ACTION.
   If the governor proclaims that a disaster emergency exists due to actual
enemy attack upon the United States or the occurrence within the state of a
major disaster resulting from enemy sabotage or other hostile action, or a
human made or natural disaster, the City Emergency Management Agency shall
cooperate fully with the State Emergency Management Agency and with the
Governor in the exercise of emergency powers as provided by law.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.402 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Emergency Management Agency of the city who are paid
employees or officers of the city, if called for training by the state director
of the Emergency Management Agency, shall receive, for the time spent in that
training, the same rate of pay as is attached to the position held. Members who
are not city employees or officers shall receive for that training time the
compensation as may be established by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.403 REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE.
   The State Treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any
reimbursement by the state to the city for expenses incident to training
members of the Emergency Management Agency of the city as prescribed by the
State Director of the Emergency Management Agency, compensation for services
and expenses of members of a mobile support team while serving outside the city
in response to a call by the Governor or the state director of the agency, as
provided by law, and any other reimbursement made by the state incident to
agency activities as provided by law.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.404 VOLUNTEERS.
   (A)   All persons other than mayoral appointments and employees of the city,
volunteering for service pursuant to this subchapter, shall serve without
compensation.
   (B)   While engaged in the service, they shall have the same immunities as
persons and employees of the city performing similar duties.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.405 INTEGRATION OF CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES.
   Appointed officers and employees of the city shall be integrated under the
division of the Emergency Management Agency of the city as the Mayor and the
Director deem necessary and expedient, and such officers and employees are
directed and authorized to comply with directives issued under this subchapter.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.406 PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES.
   (A)   The Mayor and Council may, on recommendation of the Director or on
their own motion, authorize the Director to engage in the purchase of contracts
necessary to place the city in a position to effectively combat any disaster
resulting from the explosion of any nuclear or other bomb or missile and to
protect the public health and safety, protect property and provide emergency
assistance to victims in the case of a disaster or in the case of a human made
or natural disaster.
   (B)   In the event of an enemy-caused or other disaster, the Director is
authorized, on behalf of the city, to procure such services, supplies,
equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the
exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally
prescribed by law pertaining to city contracts or obligations, as authorized by
the State ESDA Act of 1975, provided that if Council meets at such time, the
Director shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by
Council.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
Statutory reference:
   The statutes cited in this section have been repealed. Emergency management
provisions are currently set forth as the Emergency Management Agency Act, ILCS
Ch. 20, Act 3305, §§ 1 et seq.
§ 32.407 OATH.
   Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the Emergency Management
Agency of the city shall, before entering upon his or her duties, subscribe to
the following oath, in writing, which shall be filed with the Director:
   "I, _____________________, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support
and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United
States and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory,
institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all
enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any
mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully
discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or
affirm) that do not advocate, nor am I now, nor have I ever been a member of
any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the
government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that
during such time as I am affiliated with the Oak Forest Emergency Management
Agency, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or
organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence."
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.408 OFFICE SPACE.
   The Mayor and Council are authorized to designate space in a city building
or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the Mayor, for the office of the
Emergency Management Agency of the city.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.409 APPROPRIATIONS; LEVY OF TAXES.
   (A)   The Mayor and Council may make an appropriation for Emergency
Management Agency purposes in the manner provided by law and may levy, in
addition, for agency purposes only, a tax not to exceed $0.05 per $100 of the
assessed value of all taxable property in addition to all other taxes, as
provided by the State ESDA Act of 1975.
   (B)   However, that amount collectible under the levy shall in no event
exceed $0.25 per capita.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
Statutory reference:
   The statutes cited in this section have been repealed. Emergency management
provisions are currently set forth as the Emergency Management Agency Act, ILCS
Ch. 20, Act 3305, §§ 1 et seq.
§ 32.410 CREDENTIALS OF AUTHORITY.
   (A)   Credentials of authority in a manner and form to be determined by the
Director may be issued to Emergency Management Agency officers and personnel.
   (B)   The Mayor and the City Clerk are authorized to affix the seal of the
city on such credentials.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009)
§ 32.411 VIOLATIONS.
   (A)   Willfully obstruct, hinder or delay any member of the Emergency
Management Agency of the city in any enforcement of any lawful rule or
regulation issued pursuant to this subchapter or in the performance of any duty
imposed upon him or her by virtue of this subchapter;
   (B)   Do any act prohibited by any lawful rule or regulation issued pursuant
to this subchapter if such act is of a kind that will give assistance to the
enemy, imperil the life or property of any inhabitant of the city or prevent,
hinder or delay the defense or protection thereof; or
   (C)   Wear, carry or display without authority any mark or identification
specified by the agency.
(Ord. 2006-02-0006O, passed 2-28-2006; Am. Ord. 2009-12-0268O, passed 12-8-
2009) Penalty, see §
10.99
BUREAU OF FIRE INVESTIGATION
§ 32.425 PREAMBLES.
   The preambles recited in the ordinance codified in this subchapter shall be
incorporated as part of this chapter.
(2000 Code, § 2.58.010) (Ord. 2413, § 1, passed --1999)
§ 32.426 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is established within the city a Fire Investigation Bureau.
(2000 Code, § 2.58.020) (Ord. 2413, § 2, passed --1999)
§ 32.427 CONTROL AND AUTHORITY; LIAISON.
   (A)   The Fire Investigation Bureau shall be under joint control of the
Chief of each of the Oak Forest Police and Fire Departments.
   (B)   In the event of a conflict between the joint heads, the Fire Chief
shall have ultimate authority.
   (C)   The Fire and Police Chief may appoint a liaison to act as head of the
Fire Investigation Bureau.
(2000 Code, § 2.58.030) (Ord. 2413, § 3, passed --1999)
§ 32.428 PURPOSES AND DUTIES.
   (A)   This Bureau shall investigate fires to determine whether the fire was
caused as a result of carelessness or design.
   (B)   The Bureau shall develop operating procedures to aid in its work. The
Bureau shall, as needed, seek outside expertise to aid in the investigation of
the cause and origins of a fire.
(2000 Code, § 2.58.040) (Ord. 2413, § 4, passed --1999)
§ 32.429 JURISDICTION.
   (A)   The fire/arson investigator shall have the overall authority of the
remains of all areas, structures and materials involved in the fire from the
time the fire is put out until which time he or she deems it necessary to
release them.
   (B)   Upon the completion of the investigation, the arson investigator, if
appropriate, shall deliver the results of the investigation to the Police
Department.
   (C)   The Fire and Police Departments will work in full cooperation during
fire/arson investigations.
(2000 Code, § 2.58.050) (Ord. 2413, § 5, passed --1999)
§ 32.430 FIRE INVESTIGATOR QUALIFICATIONS.
   The qualifications of a fire/arson investigator shall be, at a minimum, the
following:
   (A)   A fire/arson investigation certification outlined by the Illinois
State Fire Marshal's office (120 hours);
   (B)   Firefighter III certification as outlined by the Illinois State Fire
Marshal’s Office; and
   (C)   Additional requirements as deemed necessary by the Fire and Police
Chiefs.
(2000 Code, § 2.58.060) (Ord. 2413, § 6, passed --1999)
ECONOMIC ADVISORY COUNCIL
§ 32.445 ESTABLISHMENT; PURPOSE.
   The Citizens’ Commission previously known as the Oak Forest Economic
Development Commission (EDC) shall be dissolved effective with the passage of
the ordinance codified in this subchapter, and replaced with an Economic
Advisory Council (EAC), compact in size, but specifically charged with the
following mission, agenda and/or duties:
   (A)   Promote and recommend programs and policies to improve the economic
vitality of our community, while helping to mitigate any adverse physical and
economic conditions affecting the social and economic growth of the City of Oak
Forest, now and in the future;
   (B)   Working in conjunction with the Oak Forest Chamber of Commerce, to
devise and implement an ongoing business outreach program, designed to assess
the needs and identify those issues related to government policies and/or
services which affect existing businesses in Oak Forest;
   (C)   Working in conjunction with the city’s community development staff,
research and compile an overall economic development strategy and/or marketing
plan, serving as a blueprint for the recruitment of new investment in Oak
Forest’s commercial, industrial and service sectors;
   (D)   Recommend guidelines and structure objective criteria to better
evaluate the use of development incentives as a means of business attraction
and retention;
   (E)   Compile and conduct those surveys or other research instruments
necessary to ascertain the status of the economic climate and circumstances
affecting businesses operating within the corporate limits;
   (F)   Subject to the powers and limitations granted by the City Council to
the EDC, the EAC shall be charged with the design, implementation and review of
various economic development programs, including, but not limited to, the
creation of economic development corporations, facade improvement, property tax
incentives and specific incentives directed at certain redevelopment efforts,
including the economic impact of the projects;
   (G)   Working in conjunction with the staff of various city departments, and
upon approval of the program by the City Council, review applications and
recommend to the City Council, worthy candidates for inclusion in the city’s
various economic development programs; and
   (H)   Serve as economic development ambassadors for the city conducting
various marketing and public relations activities related to the attraction of
new business investment and the retention of existing business.
(2000 Code, § 2.72.010) (Ord. 2842, § 1, passed --2004)
§ 32.446 COMPOSITION; TERMS OF OFFICE.
   (A)   The membership of the EAC shall consist of seven persons, appointed by
the Mayor, subject to the advice and consent of the City Council.
   (B)   EAC membership shall be limited to residents of Oak Forest or owners/
operators of businesses within Oak Forest, appointed at-large, but remain
representative of a cross-section of the city’s civic, business and
professional leadership, having demonstrated the skills and expertise necessary
to the implementation of a successful economic development program.
   (C)   The EAC’s membership shall serve rotating terms of three years, with
initial membership limited to the following terms of office:
      (1)   Four members shall serve for an initial term of two years; and
      (2)   Three members shall serve for an initial term of three years.
   (D)   In addition to the appointed membership from the community at-large,
one ex-officio member, an alderman, serving as the representative of, and
direct liaison to, the City Council, and the executive director of the Oak
Forest Chamber of Commerce, serving as the representative of, and direct
liaison to, the Chamber of Commerce, shall be considered full voting members of
the EAC with all rights, privileges and responsibilities, thereto assigned.
Given the unique nature of the position and the need to maintain an effective
relationship with the Chamber of Commerce, as the primary group representing
business interests which may extend outside the corporate limits of Oak Forest,
the residency requirement shall be waived for the Chamber’s executive director.
   (E)   At a minimum, meetings shall be held quarterly; however, the chair of
the EAC shall reserve the right to convene additional meetings, at the request
of the Mayor, City Council and/or community development coordinator, as
circumstances dictate.
   (F)   The EAC shall be empowered to elect a member of its body to serve as
chair, acting theretofore, as the EAC’s public spokesman, where applicable. The
city’s Community Development Coordinator and the Community Development
Department shall provide staff support to the EAC, as time, budget and staff
resources permit.
(2000 Code, § 2.72.020) (Ord. 2842, §2, passed --2004; Am. Ord. 2011-06-0345O,
passed 6-14-2011)
§ 32.447 VOLUNTEERS.
   In the conduct of its duties and responsibilities, the EAC shall be
authorized to enlist the services of those other members of the community whose
expertise and commitment to volunteer service will further expedite the
fulfillment of the EAC’s mission, agenda and duties.
(2000 Code, § 2.72.030) (Ord. 2842, § 3, passed --2004)
§ 32.448 EXPENDITURES.
   The EAC shall be authorized to obligate and/or expend funds, for purposes
stated and to the amount appropriated in the EAC’s annual budget, subject to
approval by the City Council.
(2000 Code, § 2.72.040) (Ord. 2842, § 4, passed --2004)
§ 32.449 FACADE IMPROVEMENT GRANT PROGRAM.
   (A)   The economic advisory council is authorized to implement and oversee a
facade improvement grant program to promote the continued use and maintenance
of commercial buildings in the city and to recommend the payment of grants to
business property owners for improvements to their building facades. The facade
improvement grant program shall be administered as follows:
      (1)   Grant eligibility. To be eligible for a facade improvement grant, a
building must be used in commercial or industrial purposes. Business property
owners must propose to make at least $20,000 in eligible improvements, as
defined in division (A)(3) of this section, to be eligible for a facade
improvement grant.
      (2)   Limit and nature of grant award. Facade improvement grants will be
issued to qualifying applicants in a maximum amount not greater than 33% of the
actual cost of the eligible improvements except for qualifying sign
amortization projects where the maximum amount will be not greater than 50% of
the actual cost.
      (3)   Eligible costs. The following improvement costs are eligible for
reimbursement from the facade improvement grant:
         (a)   Installation, repair and replacement of exterior exit doors to
provide public access, meet current building and fire codes, and/or improve the
overall appearance of the building;
         (b)   Painting of the exterior of the building;
         (c)   Repair, replacement or addition of exterior shutters and
awnings, except for backlit and/or plastic awnings;
         (d)   Repair and replacement of signs;
         (e)   Repair, replacement and installation of exterior stairs,
porches, railings and exit facilities;
         (f)   Repair and rebuilding of exterior walls, including cleaning,
sealing, tuck-pointing, painting and the like;
         (g)   Tuck-pointing, other repair and cleaning of exterior bricks;
         (h)   Repair of windows, frames, sills, glazing, replacement of glass,
and installation of new windows;
         (i)   Repair or construction of cornices in order to replicate the
building’s original facade;
         (j)   Repair, installation, replacement or addition of any other
improvement the City Administrator deems appropriate; and
         (k)   Landscaping and streetscape improvements including, but not
limited to brickpavers, lighting and furnishings.
      (4)   Ineligible costs. The following improvement costs are not eligible
for reimbursement from the facade improvement grant:
         (a)   Building permit fees and related costs;
         (b)   Extermination of insects, rodents, vermin and other pests;
         (c)   Title reports and legal fees;
         (d)   Acquisition of land or buildings; and
         (e)   Air conditioning and heating facilities.
   (B)   Application; submittals. Applicants under this section shall submit
the following application materials to the Community Development Director, or
his or her designee:
      (1)   Once completed and original application form, on a form approved by
and provided by the Community Development Director, which form shall include:
         (a)   Applicant’s name, address and contact information;
         (b)   Subject property common address and property identification
number;
         (c)   Legal description of subject property;
         (d)   Current use of the property;
         (e)   Improvement information, including, without limitation:
            1.   Contractor information;
            2.   Cost estimate;
            3.   Facade area;
            4.   Requested amount of grant;
            5.   Proposed improvements;
            6.   Copies of the drawings of the proposed work, to scale and
preferably in color; and
            7.   Brief narrative description of the project;
         (f)   Pictures of facade and particular areas to be enhanced; and
         (g)   Assessed value of the property.
   (C)   Economic Development Commission; review and recommendations; City
Council action.
      (1)   Upon the Community Development Director’s receipt of application
materials, he or she shall review the application to determine its completeness
with the above requirements. If an application is deemed complete by the
Economic Development Director, he or she shall submit a report to the City
Council outlining the facts, proposed improvements, and requested assistance.
      (2)   In the event that the Community Development Director finds that an
application is incomplete or that the proposed scope of improvements are
ineligible or partially ineligible for reimbursement under the facade
improvement grant program, the Community Development Director shall inform the
applicant in writing of any deficiency in his or her application or ineligible
improvements.
      (3)   Not later than 45 days after receipt of the report from the
Community Development Director, as established in division (C)(1) of this
section, the City Council shall convene to consider the application and draft
facade improvement grant agreement, which shall be approved by resolution duly
adopted with the condition that the Economic Advisory Council holds a public
meeting to approve final cost estimates.
      (4)   The Economic Advisory Council shall convene to review and approve
final cost estimates, and grantee award amount. If the applicant fails to
submit three adequate cost estimates, the Economic Advisory Council may deny
approval and/or return application back to City Council for consideration.
   (D)   Conditions. The applicant shall be subject to the following
conditions.
      (1)   Upon approval of the application, the applicant shall enter into a
facade improvement grant agreement with the City of Oak Forest the form and
substance of which to be provided by the Community Development Director, which
shall govern the use of the grant. The agreement shall be recorded with the
office of the Cook County Recorder of Deeds. The applicant shall be responsible
for all fees and costs incurred in recording the facade improvement grant
agreement.
      (2)   The applicant shall execute a restrictive covenant for the
maintenance of facade improvements. The restrictive covenant shall be recorded
with the office of the Cook County Recorder. The applicant shall be responsible
for all fees and costs incurred in recording the restrictive covenant.
      (3)   Should the applicant fail to complete the eligible cost items or
otherwise abandon the property before completion of the eligible cost items,
the city shall have a lien against the property in its favor in the amount of
the facade improvement grant released to the applicant.
      (4)   The applicant must maintain in good condition, and not change in
any manner whatsoever, without first obtaining the express prior written
consent of the City Administrator, the eligible cost items for which funds from
