§ 74.01 DEFINITIONS.
   Any term not defined in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to it
in other ordinances of the municipality, and if not defined in any other
municipal ordinance, it shall have the meaning ascribed to it in the Illinois
Vehicle Code. For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
   ABANDONED VEHICLE.
      (1)   A vehicle parked or otherwise located on a public way:
         (a)   In a state of disrepair that it is incapable of being driven; or
         (b)   That has been unmoved for a period of at least 24 hours, and
from its condition, the period during which it has not been moved, or some
other circumstance, it appears to have been, and will be presumed to have been,
abandoned by its owner.
      (2)   A vehicle parked in a public parking lot or on private property
without the consent of the lot owner or the proprietor or agent of the
property, which person has requested that the vehicle be towed; or
      (3)   A vehicle defined as abandoned, or capable of being towed, by any
other city ordinance, and which does not fall into the categories of
“hazardous” or “unlawful” vehicles and therefor is not subject to an immediate
tow.
   HAZARDOUS VEHICLE.
      (1)   A vehicle that has been involved in an accident and is disabled or
cannot be immediately moved by the owner or operator thereof;
      (2)   A vehicle that presents an immediate danger to the health or
welfare of members of the public;
      (3)   A vehicle abandoned or disabled on a public street, way or alley
that is impeding the orderly flow of traffic or that poses a potential danger
to pedestrians and other operators of vehicles; or
      (4)   A vehicle that must be moved to allow for proper municipal snow
removal from a public street, way or alley.
   OWNER. A person who holds legal title to a vehicle or the right of
possession of the vehicle.
   UNLAWFUL VEHICLE.
      (1)   A vehicle that has been reported stolen or that is the subject of a
search and seizure by the Police Department; or
      (2)   A vehicle parked in violation of state statutes or city ordinances
which prohibit parking at the location in question or for a period of time for
which the vehicle has been parked, and where either the statute or the
ordinance authorizes the vehicle to be towed and the signs posted at the
general location note that fact.
   VEHICLE. Any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn upon a street, highway or any public way, including
snowmobiles, except the devices moved by human power and devices used
exclusively upon stationary rails and tracks.
(2000 Code, § 10.36.010)
§ 74.02 AUTHORIZATION FOR TOWING.
   (A)   Generally.
      (1)   The towing of vehicles by the municipality, or by its approved
towing service operators on behalf of the municipality, shall be authorized
only by the Police Department and only under the circumstances provided in this
chapter.
      (2)   Towed vehicles shall be impounded at facilities designated by the
Police Department until lawfully claimed or disposed of pursuant to the
Illinois Vehicle Code.
   (B)   Towing without notice; immediate tows.
      (1)   A hazardous or unlawful vehicle may be towed without prior notice,
unless the vehicle is an unlawful vehicle which has been reported as stolen and
is not towable for some other specific reason, in which case the owner should,
when practical, be notified by telephone or other means and given the
opportunity to claim or move the vehicle in order to avoid incurring the
expenses of a police-ordered tow. However, the vehicle may be towed if the
owner permitted the tow to be made when the vehicle was reported stolen, or at
any time thereafter, on the form provided in §
74.10 below.
      (2)   Within 24 hours after towing a vehicle pursuant to this chapter, a
notice shall be sent or personally delivered to the owner of the vehicle,
thereby affording the owner the opportunity for a hearing as provided for in §§
74.05 and
74.06.
   (C)   Towing with prior notice; abandoned vehicles. Abandoned vehicles may
be towed after the mailing or delivery of prior notice and after affording an
opportunity for a hearing as provided for in §§
74.03 and
74.04 below.
(2000 Code, § 10.36.020)
§ 74.03 PRE-TOW NOTICE FOR ABANDONED VEHICLES.
   (A)   Notice pursuant to this section shall be personally delivered to the
owner of the vehicle or shall be forwarded by certified or registered mail,
return receipt requested, to his or her address as indicated in the most
current registration list of the Secretary of State. The notice shall be on the
form provided in §
74.08 below. If an out-of-state vehicle is proposed to be towed, inquiry by
computer, telephone or letter shall be made of the Secretary of State of the
particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the most current registered name
and address of the owner of the vehicle, and notice shall be mailed as provided
herein to the address furnished. However, in no case will the city be required
to delay towing more than seven days after the date of the mailing or personal
delivery of the notice if no request for a hearing has been received within
that seven-day period.
   (B)   A notice of intent to tow sticker, with the earliest date upon which
the tow may take place and the address and phone number of the police
department, shall be placed on the vehicle.
(2000 Code, § 10.36.030)
§ 74.04 PRE-TOW HEARING PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Opportunity for hearing.
      (1)   The owner or person entitled to possession of a vehicle to be towed
as an abandoned vehicle shall have seven days, after the date of mailing or
personal delivery of the notice, to request, in writing, a pre-tow hearing.
      (2)   Subsequent to this seven-day period, the vehicle may be towed if
the owner has not filed a written hearing request within the seven-day period,
and any hearing rights under this chapter will be deemed waived.
   (B)   Scheduling of hearing. The pre-tow hearing shall be scheduled for a
date within 14 days of the mailing or personal delivery of the pre-tow notice.
The city shall not be required to delay towing longer than the 14-day period.
   (C)   Request for hearing.
      (1)   A request for a pre-tow hearing shall be made in person to the
office indicated on the notice.
      (2)   A request for a hearing by a person who resides more than 50 miles
from the city may be made by mail.
      (3)   Forms for the requests shall be made available by the Police
Department.
      (4)   At the time of making the request, the owner will be provided a
hearing date and time, by mail or in person, as the circumstances require.
   (D)   Appointment of Hearing Officer.
      (1)   The city shall choose an officer or employee of the city to serve
as Hearing Officer.
      (2)   In no case shall a Hearing Officer be an individual who was
involved in the initial decision to tow the vehicle.
      (3)   The Hearing Officer shall have the opportunity to require the
presence of the enforcement officer who initiated the proposed tow or any other
city personnel.
   (E)   Nature of hearing.
      (1)   The hearing shall be informal in nature and the rules of evidence
shall not apply.
      (2)   The hearing will not be determinative of, or adjudicate, any
citation relative to any vehicle.
      (3)   After receiving all relevant evidence, the Hearing Officer shall
render a written decision based upon a preponderance of the evidence as to
whether towing of the vehicle is authorized by the laws of the state or the
ordinances of the city, with a specific statutory or ordinance section cited in
the decision.
      (4)   The owner shall be provided a copy of the pre-tow hearing decision.
   (F)   Decision to tow; rates to be charged.
      (1)   If a preponderance of the evidence supports towing and compliance
with this chapter, the Hearing Officer shall direct that the vehicle be towed,
with any towing and storage costs to then be imposed upon the owner thereof.
      (2)   The fees to be charged for towing and storage services shall be not
more than the maximum rates set by the Chief of Police pursuant to §
74.05(E) below.
      (3)   The owner of the vehicle, having had such a hearing, may avoid the
towing by immediately removing the vehicle from the improper location to a
lawful location and correcting any unlawful conditions of the vehicle.
   (G)   Decision not to tow.
      (1)   If a preponderance of the evidence fails to support the towing of a
vehicle, the Hearing Officer shall direct that the vehicle not be towed.
      (2)   The city shall furnish a copy of the decision to the owner, who may
place it inside the vehicle in a location plainly visible from the outside,
such as on the dashboard or inside the rear window.
      (3)   No vehicle about which such a decision has been rendered shall be
towed by the city, unless the circumstances under which the decision was
rendered have changed.
      (4)   If at some subsequent time the municipality should wish to tow the
vehicle from the same location, it shall follow the same procedures required
for the towing of any other similarly situated vehicle.
   (H)   Retention of reports and documents; contesting decisions. All original
and copies of notices, pre-tow hearing decisions, towing reports and any
associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the Police
Department for a period of at least five years after each hearing, or after
each tow if no hearing was requested or held. The city or the owner may contest
the decision of the Hearing Officer in any manner provided by law.
(2000 Code, § 10.36.040)
§ 74.05 POST-TOW NOTICE FOR HAZARDOUS AND UNLAWFUL VEHICLES.
   (A)   Mailing or delivery of notice. Notice pursuant to this section shall
be forwarded by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the
address of the owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current
registration list of the Secretary of State, unless the notice is personally
delivered to the owner, in which case the date of delivery, the time of
delivery and the name of the police officer making the delivery shall be noted
in the Police Department records or reports. The notice shall be on the forms
provided in §
74.07 below and shall be mailed or delivered within 24 hours of the tow, as
provided in §
74.02(B) above. If the city has towed an out-of-state hazardous or unlawful
vehicle, inquiry by computer, telephone or letter shall be made of the
Secretary of State of the particular jurisdiction for the furnishing of the
most current registered name and address of the owner of the vehicle, and
notice shall be mailed as provided herein to the address furnished.
   (B)   Posting of signs showing hearing rights. All approved towing service
operators shall prominently post at least one sign, with dimensions of at least
12 inches by 18 inches, indicating the opportunity and procedures for a hearing
to contest the validity of a towed vehicle. The sign, the form for which is set
out in §
74.07(A), shall be placed in locations readily visible to the public
transacting business at any towing facility. If a towing service operator
performs services for more than one city, the information for contacting the
various appropriate municipal offices can be listed in one sign, the format for
which shall be substantially similar to the form set forth in §
74.07(A).
   (C)   Requests for post-tow hearings. Requests for hearings may be made in
person at the office indicated on the notice within 15 days of the mailing or
personal delivery of the notification of tow, or release of the vehicle,
whichever occurs first; otherwise, the right to a hearing shall be deemed
waived. Requests for hearings by persons who reside more than 50 miles from the
city may be made in person or by mail received by the city within the 15-day
period.
   (D)   Release of motor vehicles. Before the owner or person entitled to
possession of any impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove the same, the
owner or person entitled to possession shall furnish evidence of his or her
identity, ownership of the vehicle or right to possession, shall sign a receipt
for the vehicle and shall pay the amount currently owed for towing and storage
fees to the towing service operator. The Chief of Police is authorized to
promulgate regulations as to the documents or other proof necessary to
establish these facts.
   (E)   Establishment of maximum towing and storage rates.
      (1)   The owner shall pay fees to the towing service operator for towing
and storage on police-ordered tows at rates not to exceed maximum amounts to be
administratively established by the Chief of Police and which may be revised
from time to time.
      (2)   The basic rates for the fees shall be shown in the form and sign
concerning vehicle release requirements, as set forth in §
74.07(A). However, nothing in this section is intended to prevent a competitive
towing service operator from charging less than the established maximum rates
for police-ordered tows or any other tows. In arriving at the maximum rates for
various services, the Chief shall consider the matters as the prevalent market
rates in the area for the different types of vehicles, the types of storage and
area requirements for categories as large trucks and commercial vehicles and
the relative difficulties and amount of work required to perform various types
of towing operations.
      (3)   For particularly difficult or unusual towing jobs, such as large or
serious accidents, the Chief is authorized to allow towing operators to charge
rates above those established for normal situations. Those special charges must
be based upon the cost of services provided, taking into account matters as the
man-hours and equipment time required for the job.
      (4)   A towing service operator shall fully itemize, in writing, the
details of a billing at special rates for a particularly difficult or unusual
tow and shall supply a copy of the itemized bill to the owner and to the Police
Department. Any special rates charged shall be customary in the towing industry
in the area for the nature and extent of the services provided.
      (5)   Every towing service operator and the Police Department shall make
available a copy of the complete current rate schedule and any special rate
policy established by the Chief of Police, for vehicle owners to view upon
request.
(2000 Code, § 10.36.050)
§ 74.06 POST-TOW HEARING PROCEDURES.
   (A)   Opportunity for hearing. The owner of a vehicle towed as an immediate
tow, by or pursuant to the authority of the Police Department as set forth in §
74.02 above, shall be provided an opportunity for a post-tow hearing to
determine the validity of the tow and any towing or storage charges. The
hearing will not be determinative of, or adjudicate, any citation issued
relative to any towed vehicle.
   (B)   Nature of the hearing; appointment of Hearing Officer. The nature of
the hearing and the appointment of the Hearing Officer shall be the same as set
forth in §
74.04(D) and (E).
   (C)   Scheduling of hearings. Hearings shall take place as follows:
      (1)   In those instances where a vehicle has been released upon the
deposit of the full payment currently owed for towing and storage charges, and
the owner has properly requested a hearing, the hearing shall take place within
15 days after the release of the vehicle, unless the owner requests a later
date convenient to all parties.
      (2)   In those instances where a vehicle remains impounded, the hearing
shall take place, at the option of the owner:
         (a)   On the next day after an owner’s demand for the hearing,
excluding Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, if such demand is made after 3:00
p.m.;
         (b)   On the second day following the demand, excluding Saturdays,
Sundays and holidays, if the unavailability of a necessary witness or evidence
creates a particular difficulty in conducting the hearing on the next calendar
day; or
         (c)   Within 15 days of the request, on a date convenient to all
parties, if acceptable to the owner.
   (D)   Conduct of hearings. The Hearing Officer shall review all evidence
presented by the vehicle owner and the Police Department or other city
employees and shall make a finding, based upon a preponderance of the evidence
presented, as to the lawful authority for the towing and storage of the
vehicle. The city must establish the authority by a preponderance of the
evidence.
   (E)   Hearing decision. For each hearing, the Hearing Officer shall complete
a post-tow hearing decision, shall attach the decision to the Police
Department’s original vehicle towing report, and shall supply a copy of the
decision to the owner by personal delivery, if the owner is present, or by
mail, if the owner isn’t present. The decision and findings shall be
substantially as stated in the form for a post-tow hearing decision, set forth
in §
74.09 below.
   (F)   Retention of reports and documents; contesting decisions. All
originals and copies of notices, post-tow hearing decisions, towing reports and
any associated police reports or documents shall be retained by the Police
Department for a period of at least five years after each hearing, or after
each tow if no hearing was requested or held. The city or the owner may contest
the decision of the Hearing Officer in any manner provided by law.
   (G)   Compliance with chapter. Notwithstanding any other ordinance or
statutory provision to the contrary, any towing service operator authorized to
perform tows on behalf of the city must perform its services subject to the
provisions of this chapter. However, the towing company shall have the right to
recover the reasonable value of its services for police-ordered tows, which are
not paid by the vehicle owner, from the city. However, if a tow or the charge
for a tow is found to be illegal and the towing service operator is required to
return the charge for the tow to the owner of the vehicle, the city shall not
be liable to reimburse the operator for the towing charges.
(2000 Code, § 10.36.060)
§ 74.07 FORM FOR POST-TOW NOTICE AND SIGNS.
   (A)   The following form shall be utilized in the administration of §§
74.05 and
74.06 above for posting in towing establishments and for mailing or delivering
to owners:
NOTICE OF VEHICLE RELEASE REQUIREMENTS AND HEARING RIGHTS
   Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any impounded vehicle
shall be permitted to remove the same from custody of the Police Department or
towing service operator, he shall furnish evidence of his identity and
ownership of the vehicle and right of possession thereto, shall sign a receipt
for the vehicle, and shall pay a fee not exceeding $ _____ and for a truck or
commercial vehicle, to cover the cost of towing or removal to a vehicle pound
or authorized garage, and, in addition thereto, the cost of storage, not
exceeding $ ______ per day for a passenger vehicle of not more than seven
passengers, and $ ______ per day for a truck or commercial vehicle.
   However, higher fees may necessarily be charged in particularly difficult or
unusual towing or storage circumstances, for which rate information is
available upon request at the Police Department or towing business location. If
the owner or person entitled to possession wishes to contest the validity of
the tow, he may obtain a hearing under the conditions of either paragraph (A)
or (B) stated below:
TO OBTAIN HEARING
   (A)   If the vehicle has been released, he may, within fifteen days of the
release of the vehicle or the mailing or personal delivery to him of the
notification of the tow, whichever occurs first, request a hearing by
contacting in person the office of (Name of office, address and phone number)
Anyone residing more than fifty miles away from the City of Oak Forest may make
a request for a hearing by mail. The right to any hearing will be deemed waived
unless a written request for hearing is received by the above office within the
applicable fifteen-day period.
   (B)   If the vehicle is still impounded, he may contact the above officer
and obtain a hearing within the next day after the request, excluding
Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, unless the request is made after 3:00 p.m., or
unless there are particular difficulties in having the hearing on the next day,
in which case the hearing will take place on the second day thereafter,
excluding weekends and holidays.
NATURE OF HEARING
   (A)   The hearing shall be conducted according to municipal ordinance
provisions and shall determine the validity of the impounding of the vehicle
and the imposition or refund of any towing or storage charges, but the hearing
will not determine or adjudicate any citations issued. If the Hearing Officer
sustains the validity of the tow and storage, the owner or person entitled to
possession will be required to pay all unpaid towing and storage fees before
obtaining the release of the vehicle.
   (B)   The following form shall be utilized in the administration of §§
74.05 and
74.06 for the mailing or delivery of post-tow notices to owners, including the
form set forth in division (A) above:

§ 74.10 FORM FOR OWNER’S PERMISSION TO TOW STOLEN VEHICLE.
   The following form shall be used by police officers when obtaining
permission from vehicle owners to tow stolen vehicles that are recovered:
PERMISSION TO TOW STOLEN VEHICLE FORM
   I, _____________________(name of owner), am the owner of a motor vehicle
which I have reported to the Oak Forest Police Department as having been
stolen. The vehicle is described as follows: _________________
___________________________________________________________________________________________
____________________________________________________________________
(description of the vehicle)
   I understand that the Oak Forest Police Department may transmit notice of
this vehicle theft to other police agencies which may attempt to recover the
vehicle. I understand that if the vehicle is recovered, I have the option of
requesting that the vehicle be towed to a vehicle pound location or left at the
place where the vehicle has been found. While not requiring the law enforcement
agency which finds the vehicle to do so, I do hereby grant my permission to
have the vehicle towed. I understand that if the vehicle is towed, I will be
required to pay reasonable towing and storage charges.

(2000 Code, § 10.36.100)
CHAPTER 75: BICYCLES
Section
   
75.01   Registration required
   
75.02   Application for registration
   
75.03   Registration tags or stickers
   
75.04   Sales or transfers
   
75.05   Responsibility of rental agencies
   
75.06   Bicycle stores; records of sales
   
75.07   Destruction of manufacturer’s serial number
§ 75.01 REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person residing within the city shall operate or permit to be operated
any bicycle upon the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city, unless the
bicycle is registered as provided in this chapter and unless the city
registration tag or sticker is affixed in a prominent place to the bicycle.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.010) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 75.02 APPLICATION FOR REGISTRATION.
   All applications for a bicycle registration, or for the transfer thereof,
shall be made in writing to the City Clerk or his or her designee, on forms to
be furnished by the City Clerk, which shall state the make, serial number,
model and description of the bicycle to be registered, the name and residence
address of the owner of the bicycle, the signature of the owner, the owner’s
age, and, if the owner is under 18 years of age, the name and address of his or
her parent or guardian, the name and address of the person from whom the
bicycle was purchased and the date of purchase.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.020)
§ 75.03 REGISTRATION TAGS OR STICKERS.
   Upon receipt of an application for registration of a bicycle, the City Clerk
or his or her designee shall register the bicycle and deliver to the applicant
a registration tag or sticker to be affixed to the bicycle.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.030)
§ 75.04 SALES OR TRANSFERS.
   Upon the sale or transfer of any bicycle registered under this chapter, the
purchaser or transferee, within ten days of the date of the sale or transfer,
shall register the bicycle in his or her name in the manner provided for in the
case of an original registrant.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.040)
§ 75.05 RESPONSIBILITY OF RENTAL AGENCIES.
   A rental agency shall not rent or offer any bicycle for rent unless the
bicycle is registered in accordance with this chapter.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.050) Penalty, see §
10.99
§ 75.06 BICYCLE STORES; RECORDS OF SALES.
   Every person engaged in the business of buying or selling new or secondhand
bicycles shall make a report to the City Clerk of every bicycle purchased or
sold by that person, giving the name and address of the person from whom the
bicycle is purchased or to whom sold, and the make, serial number, model and
registration number, if any, of the bicycle.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.060)
§ 75.07 DESTRUCTION OF MANUFACTURER’S SERIAL NUMBER.
   No person shall destroy, remove, alter, cover or deface the manufacturer’s
serial number on any bicycle and no person shall own or have custody of a
bicycle if the original manufacturer’s serial number thereof has been
destroyed, removed, altered, covered or defaced.
(2000 Code, § 10.40.070) Penalty, see §
10.99
CHAPTER 76: TRAFFIC SCHEDULES
Schedule
   
I.   Limited vehicular access
   
II.   Turning movements
   
III.   Stop and yield signs
SCHEDULE I. LIMITED VEHICULAR ACCESS.
   Vehicular access from the frontage referenced in Ord. 2125, passed 12-19-
1995, to 167th Street, Dan Ryan Expressway (1-57), Cicero Avenue and/or
Crawford Avenue/Pulaski Road, at locations other than the existing frontage
road termini, is prohibited.
(2000 Code, § 10.16.050A)
SCHEDULE II. TURNING MOVEMENTS.
   Left turn only (3:30 p.m. to 6:30 p.m.): Southbound Oak Avenue at 160th
Street.
(Ord. 2007-11-0140O, passed 11-27-2007)

CHAPTER 77: PARKING SCHEDULES
Schedule
   
I.   Prohibited parking
   
II.   Residential parking areas
   
III.   No parking this side of street
SCHEDULE I. PROHIBITED PARKING.
   (A)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle in any of the
following areas: On the east side or west side of Central Avenue between 163rd
Street on the south and Margie Lane on the north.
   (B)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle on 163rd Street
from Long Avenue to Central Avenue on either side of the street from 9:00 p.m.
to 6:00 a.m. of the following day.
   (C)   Parking shall not be permitted along 151st Street from Oak Park Avenue
to Chestnut Road within the city limits. Council shall prohibit future parking
at locations on or immediately adjacent to 151st Street as may be determined
and directed by the County of Cook to be necessary to ensure the free flow of
traffic and safety to the motoring public.
   (D)   No person shall park, stand or stop any motor vehicle on El Vista
Avenue from 151st Street to LaPalm Drive, or on Vine Street from Sunset Avenue
to Mission Avenue. Limits: "Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days
8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m."
   (E)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle at 151st Street on
El Vista Avenue. Limits: "No Parking Here to Corner."
   (F)   No person shall park any vehicle between the signs posted on Mission
Avenue at 151st Street.
   (G)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle from Waverly
Avenue to Cicero Avenue on the south side of 156th Street. Limits: "No Parking
Anytime."
   (H)   Parking shall not be permitted along Route 50 (Cicero Avenue) from
149th Street to Route 6 within the city limits. Council shall prohibit future
parking at locations on or immediately adjacent to Route 50 (Cicero Avenue) as
may be determined and directed by the state and the city to be necessary to
ensure the free flow of traffic and safety to the motoring public.
   (I)   No person shall park, stand or stop any motor vehicle on the north
side of 151st Street between Central Avenue and Long Avenue. Limits: "No
Parking Anytime."
   (J)   No person shall park, stand or stop any motor vehicle on Fawn Court.
Limits: "Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days - 8:00 a.m. to 4:00
p.m."
   (K)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the areas and
in violation of the limits as indicated below: Area: North side of Waverly
Avenue between Cicero Avenue and 156th Street. Limits: "6:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m."
   (L)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not displaying a residential
parking permit, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose operators are
doing business with the residents living at these addresses, at the following
location: Chaucer Drive from Victoria Drive to Rob Roy Drive. Limits: "Resident
Parking Only - No Parking on School Days 8:00 a.m. to 3:00 p.m."
   (M)   The area commonly described as the west side of Long Avenue from 151st
Street to Woodland Drive is designated as a "No Parking Area."
   (N)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the area and
in violation of the limits as indicated below: Area: Ann Marie and Natalie
Drives south of 155th Street. Limits: Posted signs on the side of the streets
where fire hydrants exist.
   (O)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the area and
in violation of the limits as indicated below: Area: From 15420/21 and Hickory
Lane to Victoria Drive. Limits: "No Parking Here to Corner -School Days Only."
   (P)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not registered to a resident of
that street, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose operators are doing
business with the residents living at these addresses, at the following
location: Sunset Park and El Vista Avenues from LaPalm Drive South. Limits:
"Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days 8:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m."
   (Q)   No person shall park, stand or stop a motor vehicle from 12:00 p.m. to
4:00 p.m. during school days on Long Avenue from Diamond Drive to 155th Street.
   (R)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not registered to a resident of
that street, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose operators are doing
business with the residents living at these addresses, at the following
location: 5340 and 5350 West 146th Street.
   (S)   It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle within the areas and
in violation of the limits as indicated below: No parking here to corner on
both the East and West sides of Laramie Avenue from 16700 to Aldersyde.
   (T)   Parking shall not be permitted along the following streets:
      (1)   Oak from 159th Street to 160th Street;
      (2)   160th Street from Oak Street to Cicero Avenue;
      (3)   160th Street from Oak Avenue to Grove Avenue (north side); and
      (4)   Forest Avenue from 159th Street to 160th Street (east side).
   (U)   Pursuant to §
73.10. it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in the following location:
north side of Victoria Drive (between 5630 Victoria Drive and Chaucer Drive).
   (V)   Pursuant to §
73.10. it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle between the east exit and west
entrance at 5151 W. 149th Street commonly known as Ridge School. This will be
indicated by “No Parking” signs erected, installed and maintained by the
Director of Public Works.
   (W)   Pursuant to §
73.10, it shall be unlawful to park, stand or stop any vehicle on any of the
following streets during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. to
4:00 p.m. Limits: “Resident Parking Only - No Parking on School Days 7:00 a.m.
to 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. to 4:00 p.m.” This will be indicated by “No Parking”
signs erected, installed and maintained by the Director of Public Works.

SCHEDULE II: RESIDENTIAL PARKING AREAS.
   (A)   Establishment. The city creates certain residential parking areas.
These areas shall include the following:
      (1)   Mission Avenue between 151st Street and LaPalm Drive;
      (2)   Sunset Avenue between Vine Street and LaPalm Drive;
      (3)   Park Avenue between Vine Street and LaPalm Drive;
      (4)   Lamon Avenue from 155th Street on the south to 153rd Street on the
north;
      (5)   The area from 15300 to 15400 Kilpatrick Avenue;
      (6)   The area on Fern Avenue between Central and Major Avenues;
      (7)   The area on Chestnut Lane between 151st Street and Forestview
Drive;
      (8)   The area on Willow Lane between 151st Street and Forestview Drive;
      (9)   The area on Spruce Lane between 151st Street and Forestview Drive;
      (10)   Oak Avenue Commuter Lot Area Permit Parking Only Zone 2 weekdays
from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m. on:
         (a)   Forest Avenue from 159th Street to 160th Street (west side
only);
         (b)   Forest Avenue from 160th Street to 162nd Street;
         (c)   Oak Avenue from 160th Street to 162nd Street;
         (d)   Grove Avenue from 159th Street to 160th Street;
         (e)   Lavergne Avenue (north and south of 160th to the terminus);
         (f)   160th Street from Oak to Lavergne (south side);
         (g)   160th Street from Grove Avenue to Laverne Avenue (north side);
and
         (h)   161st Street from Cicero to Forest Avenue;
      (11)   The area on Long Avenue between 151st and Diamond Drive;
      (12)   The area north of 155th Street on Ann Marie Drive, Betty Ann Lane,
Michaele Drive and Natalie Drive is designated as a residential parking permit
only area on school days from 10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.;
      (13)   Creekside Drive and Crescent Lane are designated as residential
parking permit only areas on school days;
      (14)   Kara Court is designated as a residential parking permit zone;
      (15)   Latrobe from 157th Street to 160th Street; and
      (16)   158th Street from Laramie Avenue; and
      (17)   East side of Laramie Avenue from 158th to 159th and the north
property line of 15742 Laramie to 159th Street on the west side of Laramie
Avenue.
   (B)   Parking permits required.
      (1)   It is unlawful to park any vehicle not displaying a residential
parking permit in an area designated as a residential parking area in division
(A)(1) through (3) above, excluding service or delivery vehicles whose
operators are doing business with residents in such areas, between 8:00 a.m.
and 2:00 p.m. on days when school is in session at Oak Forest High School.
      (2)   It is unlawful for anyone to park any motor vehicle in an area
designated as a residential parking area in division (A)(4) through (17) above
unless it displays a parking permit.
   (C)   Permit issuance. The city shall issue one residential parking permit
for each vehicle bearing a current City of Oak Forest vehicle sticker and which
is based from a single-family dwelling on the street designated as a
residential parking permit area. The permits shall be restricted to use to the
vehicle for which the permit was issued.
   (D)   In addition, the city shall issue two residential parking permits for
visitors to any residence in the residential parking permit area. Visitors'
parking is limited to the time that the person driving the visiting vehicle is
actually in the residence or on the property being visited. Additional one-day
visitor's permits may be obtained from the city for special events. Any misuse
of any permits shall render them invalid and additional permits shall not be
issued to the person or household which originally held the same.
   (E)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to any service or
delivery vehicle when used to provide services or to make deliveries to
residences within a residential parking permit area, provided that the parking
of the vehicle does not exceed the time the services or deliveries are being
made.
   (F)   Display of permits; limitations.
      (1)   All resident permits shall be displayed on or about the left side
of the front windshield of the vehicle so as to be easily visible from the
outside of the vehicle.
      (2)   The parking permit shall not guarantee or reserve a parking space
within the designated residential parking permit area. The permit shall not
authorize the standing or parking of any vehicle in such places as the
stopping, standing or parking of vehicles is otherwise prohibited. Nothing in
this chapter shall excuse the observance of any traffic regulation.
   (G)   (1)   If otherwise allowed by city ordinance the city may issue a
residential parking permit for motor vehicles owned by the resident's employer
and regularly used by the resident. Before issuance of a permit for such
vehicle, the city shall be provided the following proof:
         (a)   Vehicle ownership;
         (b)   A statement from the employer that the vehicle has been
permanently assigned to the resident for his or her use; and
         (c)   As a condition of the resident's employment the employee is
authorized or directed to keep the vehicle in the employee's possession.
      (2)   Supplemental documentation may be requested by the city. Nothing in
this provision is intended to nor shall it allow the parking of any vehicles
above a "B" classification.
   (H)   Permits shall be issued on an annual basis concurrent with the
issuance of municipal vehicle stickers.
   (I)   Permits shall be permanently displayed in the lower left hand corner
of the vehicle’s rear window.
   (J)   Misrepresentations; duplicate permits.
      (1)   It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to represent
that a vehicle is entitled to a parking permit authorized by this chapter when
it is not so entitled. The display of a parking permit on a vehicle not
entitled to a parking permit shall constitute a representation.
      (2)   It shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to duplicate
or attempt to duplicate, by any means, a parking permit authorized by this
chapter. It shall also be a violation of this chapter for any person to display
on any vehicle a duplicate parking permit.
   (K)   Violation; penalty.
      (1)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be subject to the penalties provided in §
10.99 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
      (2)   In addition, the city expressly incorporates the provisions of the
city towing ordinances, specifically including, but not limited to,
Chapter 74.
(2000 Code, §§ 10.32.010 through 10.32.060) (Ord. 2676, § 2, passed - -2002;
Am. Ord. 2018-07-0695, passed 7-24-2018; Am. Ord. 2018-08-0700O, passed - -
2018)

STREET AND BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION
§ 90.001 IDOT STANDARD SPECIFICATIONS FOR ROAD AND BRIDGE CONSTRUCTION; FILE
COPIES.
   (A)   There is adopted by and for the city, for the purpose of prescribing
regulations governing construction and material specifications for streets and
other public ways in the city, that certain document known as Standard
Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, the most current edition,
prepared and promulgated by the Illinois Department of Transportation (IDOT),
or any successor edition of the aforementioned publication.
   (B)   At least three copies of that document are on file with the City Clerk
for inspection by the public.
(2000 Code, § 12.04.010)
§ 90.002 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall violate or fail to comply with any of the provisions of the
Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, as adopted in §
90.001 above, in the repair, improvement or construction of any street or other
public way in the city.
(2000 Code, § 12.04.020) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.003 CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   (A)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of the
Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge Construction, as adopted in §
90.001 above, and any provision of these codified ordinances, or any other
local ordinance or resolution, the provision of the Standard Specifications for
Road and Bridge Construction shall control.
   (B)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of the
document and a provision of any other technical code adopted or referred to by
the city as a standard, the higher or stricter standard shall control.
(2000 Code, § 12.04.030)
SIDEWALK CONSTRUCTION
§ 90.015 SIDEWALKS REQUIRED.
   (A)   Public sidewalks shall be installed on all new residential, commercial
and institutional construction.
   (B)   Sidewalks shall also be required where they do not exist on any
remodeling projects and where, in the determination of the Director of Public
Works, the interest of the city would require installation of the sidewalk.
   (C)   Sidewalks are required on the full street frontage of the lot and on
the side lot frontage on corner lots that border a public street.
   (D)   This section shall also apply to properties governed by the
subdivision regulations.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.010) (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)
§ 90.016 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall repair or install a public sidewalk without first obtaining
a written permit therefor from the City Building Department.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.020) (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.017 PERMIT APPLICATIONS.
   Applications for sidewalk repair or installation permits shall be made on
forms furnished by the city.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.030)
§ 90.018 PERMIT FEES.
   Fees for a sidewalk installation permit shall be in accordance with the
applicable building permit fees and inspection fees as prescribed in Title 15
of this code.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.040) (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001; Ord. 2006-09-
0054O, passed 9-12-2006)
§ 90.019 GRADE AND ALIGNMENT STANDARDS.
   Applicants shall comply with the following standard provisions for sidewalk
construction:
   (A)   The minimum width shall be five feet;
   (B)   The minimum thickness shall be five inches with a two-inch sand or
stone cushion;
   (C)   The beginning distance from the property line shall be one foot;
   (D)   The grade shall follow a line sloping up and away from the top of the
curb at a slope of one-fourth inch per foot; and
   (E)   Concrete shall be subject to a 28-day compression test for a six-bag
mix; three to six percent air entrainment shall be 3,500 psi.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.060)
§ 90.020 VARIANCES.
   (A)   The city may authorize variances from standard sidewalk provisions set
forth in §
90.019 where no curb exists or when unusual topographical conditions, nature of
existing construction or similar factors would make adherence to the provisions
unreasonable.
   (B)   The variance shall only be approved by the Mayor and City Council.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.070) (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001; Ord. 2006-09-
0054O, passed 9-12-2006)
§ 90.021 GRADE AND LINE REQUIRED.
   No sidewalk shall be installed unless a grade and line are established
therefor. If no grade or line is available, a sidewalk may be installed with an
appropriate permit. However, if or when the city establishes a grade and line,
the city may remove, modify or replace the sidewalk to conform to the grade and
line at the city’s expense.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.080) (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.022 CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS.
   Sidewalks shall be constructed in accordance with details and specifications
in §
90.019 above.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.090) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.023 INSPECTIONS.
   All work shall be subject to inspection by the city during construction and
upon completion. A permittee shall notify the city after forms are set, and no
concrete shall be poured or further construction started until the forms are
approved by the city.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.100) (Ord. 2506, § 2 (part), passed - -2001)
§ 90.024 OCCUPANCY PERMITS.
   (A)   The requirements set forth in this chapter must be met before an
occupancy permit is issued by the city.
   (B)   The Building Commissioner may issue a temporary occupancy permit, as
provided for in the city’s Building Codes and regulations.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.110) (Ord. 2006-09-0054O, passed 9-12-2006)
§ 90.025 WAIVER; PAYMENT TO CITY IN LIEU OF SIDEWALKS.
   (A)   Whenever, in the opinion of the city, the installation of a public
sidewalk would serve no public purpose, that requirement may be waived.
   (B)   If it is determined that the installation of a public sidewalk is
unnecessary, the owner shall, in lieu thereof, pay over to the city an amount
of money, which shall be equal to the current cost of construction of the
sidewalk based on the city’s most recent per lineal foot cost of sidewalk
installation times the lineal width of the subject lot.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.120) (Ord. 2506, § 2 (part), passed - -2001)
§ 90.026 SIDEWALK FUND.
   The City Treasurer shall establish a sidewalk fund. Moneys paid to the city
pursuant to §
90.025 above shall be deposited and held by the City Treasurer in the fund and
shall be disbursed from time to time for the purpose of installation,
improvement and repair of city sidewalks upon the direction of Council.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.130)

   (B)   All driveways constructed shall be as specified by the Building

2011; Am. Ord. 2021-03-0830O, passed 3-23-2021)
§ 90.043 DRIVEWAY GRADES AND CURBS.
   (A)   Driveways shall be level with existing adjoining sidewalk grades.
   (B)   Where it is necessary to saw, cut or break the existing curb for the
driveway opening, the curb and gutter shall be completely removed and a new
section constructed.
   (C)   Each such driveway shall be constructed and maintained so as to permit
free and unobstructed passage in such a manner as not to interfere with the
proper drainage of the streets.
   (D)   Gradual approaches to the regular sidewalk grade shall be one inch
above the gutter slab.
   (E)   The slope of the driveway and to the approaches thereto shall not
exceed a six percent slope in any direction.
   (F)   Each such driveway shall be constructed and maintained so that its
surface, at the point of crossing any sidewalk pavement, shall be flush with
the adjoining sections of the sidewalk.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.044 CONNECTION TO COLLECTOR OR ARTERIAL STREETS.
   (A)   Driveways connecting to collector or arterial streets must provide an
on-site turn around.
   (B)   Where a lot fronts both a local street and a collector or arterial
street, no driveways shall be installed along the property line of the lot that
fronts the arterial or collector street
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.045 PLACEMENT OF DRIVEWAY.
   At no time shall any portion of a driveway be closer to a side property line
than one foot.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.046 REMOVAL OF PARKWAY TREES.
   (A)   At no time shall any parkway tree be removed to allow for the
installation or portion thereof, of any driveway; provided, however, that the
property owner may request in writing that the Mayor and City Council waive
this prohibition upon a finding of undue hardship.
   (B)   Where an undue hardship is determined, in the sole and absolute
discretion, by the Mayor and City Council, this provision may be waived, for
removal of the tree.
   (C)   The Mayor and City Council may require that the property owner:
      (1)   Reimburse the city for the current fair market value of the tree
that is removed; or
      (2)   Replace the parkway tree with the same or similar species with
approximately the same caliper width.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)

152.37 of this code.

   No person shall construct or maintain a private drive or roadway from any
public street in the city over or across any drainage ditch now or hereafter
existing, unless he or she installs and maintains a culvert thereunder in

(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.049 CULVERT PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall install a culvert under any private drive or roadway unless
a permit therefor is first applied for and obtained from the Director of Public
Works.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.050 GRADE AND SIZE.
   Upon an application for a permit required by §
90.049, the Director of Public Works or the City Engineer shall forthwith
establish the grade for and prescribe the size of the proposed culvert.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.051 MATERIALS.
   Every culvert shall be of a size determined by the Director of Public Works
to be adequate to permit the free flow of water in a ditch and shall be
corrugated galvanized steel, reinforced concrete, cast iron or such other
material that meets with the approval of the Director of Public Works.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.052 INSTALLATION.
   Every culvert shall be installed in conformity with the flow of a ditch and
in a manner prescribed by the Director of Public Works so it will not impede
the normal flow of water in the ditch and so there will be no stagnant water
standing or retained behind it.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.053 CHANGE OF GRADE PROHIBITED.
   No person installing a culvert shall change the grade of the ditch in which
the culvert is being installed from the grade established and prescribed by the
Director of Public Works or the City Engineer.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.054 REFUSE IN CULVERTS; OBSTRUCTIONS TO WATER FLOW.
   Any person who maintains a private drive or roadway across any ditch into
premises owned or occupied by him or her shall keep the culvert thereunder
clean and free from all refuse and matter which may impede the free flow of
water in the ditch.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.055 NOTICE TO CLEAN; CLEANING BY CITY.
   (A)   If a culvert becomes plugged or clogged, the owner or occupant of the
property into which a private drive or roadway over the culvert leads shall be
notified to clean the same within 24 hours after notification. The notification
shall be made in writing and may be served by delivering the same to the owner
or occupant personally or by posting the same on the premises.
   (B)   If the owner or occupant fails to clean the culvert within 24 hours
after notification, the city shall cause the culvert to be cleaned and shall
charge all expenses of such cleaning to the owner or occupant.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.056 APPLICATION TO EXISTING CULVERTS.
   If an existing culvert under any private drive or roadway fails to comply
with this chapter, or impedes the free flow of water in the ditch in which it
is installed, the owner or occupant of the property into which the drive or
roadway leads, upon notice from the city, shall install a proper culvert in
accordance with this chapter.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.057 REMOVAL AND REPLACEMENT BY CITY.
   Any existing culvert that has been approved as to size, material and
location by the city and any such culvert hereafter approved as to size,
material and location by the city, which subsequently is ordered to be removed
by the city, shall be removed and replaced at the sole expense of the city.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.058 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall repair or install a driveway, or any addition to an existing
driveway, without first obtaining a written permit therefor from the City
Building Department.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.059 CONCRETE DRIVES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide specifications for
materials and construction of concrete drives in all residentially zoned
districts.
   (B)   General specifications. Materials and construction for residential
drives shall conform to § 406, Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction, Illinois Department of Transportation, most current edition,, or
any successor edition thereto, except as stated in divisions (C) through (E)
below.
   (C)   Materials.
      (1)   Aggregate. The stone aggregate shall conform to § 704 of the
standard specifications, except as follows:
         (a)   The gradation of the stone shall be CA6 or CA7, that is “State
Road Mix;”
         (b)   No pea gravel, chips or tunnel rock shall be allowed; and
         (c)   No slag shall be used; only limestone is permitted.
      (2)   Concrete. Concrete driveways shall be constructed with a minimum of
six sacks of cement per cubic yard. The minimum compressive strength of 4,000
psi at 28 days, maximum size aggregate of one inch, air entrainment of 6% plus
1%, maximum slump of four inches, maximum water content including moisture in
the aggregate of six gallons per sack of cement, and all concrete shall contain
a water-reducing admixture with no reduction in cement content permitted.
   (D)   Thickness.
      (1)   Aggregate base. The aggregate base shall be a minimum of two inches
thick.
      (2)   Concrete. The concrete for a driveway, other than the apron, shall
be a minimum of four inches thick with reinforcement or five full inches thick
without reinforcement. The apron shall consist of a full seven inches with no
reinforcement.
   (E)   Forms. Side forms shall be of lumber of not less than two inches
nominal thickness or steel of equal rigidity. The minimum depth of the side
forms shall be equal to the driveway thickness. No two-inch by four-inch lumber
forms shall be permitted. Forms shall be held securely in place by stakes or
braces with the top edge true to line and grade.
   (F)   Expansion joints. Expansion joints of the thickness specified below
shall consist of a premolded filler strip with the top strip placed one-fourth
inch below the surface of the driveway. One-half inch thick expansion joints
shall be provided at the junction of the driveway apron and the sidewalk and at
the junction of the driveway apron and the curb.
   (G)   Backfill. After the concrete has been cured, forms shall be removed
and the space near the edges of the driveway shall be backfilled to the
required elevation and the material shall be compacted until firm and the
surface evenly graded.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.060 ASPHALT DRIVES IN RESIDENTIAL AREAS.
   (A)   Purpose. The purpose of this section is to provide specifications for
materials and construction of asphalt drives in residentially zoned districts.
   (B)   General specifications. Materials and construction for residential
drives shall conform to § 406, Standard Specifications for Road and Bridge
Construction, Illinois Department of Transportation, adopted October 1, 1983,
as amended, except as stated in divisions (C) to (E) below.
   (C)   Materials.
      (1)   Aggregate. The stone aggregate shall conform to § 704 of the
standard specifications, except as follows:
         (a)   The gradation of the stone shall be CA6, that is “State Road
Mix;”
         (b)   No pea gravel, chips or tunnel rock shall be allowed; and
         (c)   No slag shall be used; only limestone is permitted.
      (2)   Bituminous asphalt. The bituminous asphalt surface course shall be
Class 1, Mixture C, modified in accordance with §§ 406 and 704.03 of the
standard specifications, except that CA16 aggregate gradation shall be used.
The asphalt cement shall be AC WO to 120, that is a “State Fine Mix.”
   (D)   Thickness.
      (1)   Aggregate base. The crushed stone aggregate base shall be eight
inches thick.
      (2)   Bituminous asphalt surface course. The surface course shall be two
inches thick.
   (E)   Construction.
      (1)   Sub-base preparation.
         (a)   The overdig of the foundation in front of a garage door shall be
backfilled with crushed stone. No clay or black dirt shall be used as backfill.
The backfill shall be hand tamped.
         (b)   The drive area shall be cleared of all construction debris,
drywall, wood, loose clay and black dirt. Should the sub-base need to be
brought to grade, no clay backfill is allowed. Any sub-base overdig shall be
filled with stone.
         (c)   The sub-base shall be rolled and compacted to a distance of one
foot beyond the width of the drive. The sub-base must be dry, so that no sub-
base material sticks to the roller.
      (2)   Aggregate base. The crushed stone aggregate shall be placed in two
four-inch lifts, compacted after each lift. The contractor shall wet each lift
before rolling.
      (3)   Asphalt surface course.
         (a)   The asphalt surface shall be placed in one two-inch lift.
         (b)   The surface shall be rolled smooth such as to leave no roller
marks.
         (c)   Care shall be taken to hand tamp and roll next to walks and
garage apron areas.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.061 GRAVEL DRIVES.
   No existing gravel driveway shall be enlarged, altered or otherwise changed
without the property owner:
   (A)   Obtaining a permit, as required by the chapter; and
   (B)   Constructing any such enlargement, alteration or change in conformity
with the standards set forth in this chapter.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
§ 90.062 APRONS AND ACCESSWAYS.
   (A)   Aprons or other accessways constructed from the edge of the pavement
of a curbed city street across public and/or private property to serve
residential, commercial or other purposes can be of asphalt, concrete or brick
paver materials. Any material installed in the apron of other than plain
concrete or plain asphalt will be installed at the owner's risk. An apron or
accessway of an alternate material such as brick paver, stamped, colored or
aggregate concrete or stamped asphalt will require a waiver from the owner
releasing and absolving the city of any responsibility or liability in
connection with the apron or accessway. The waiver must be signed by owner at
time of building permit procurement. New driveway and apron or replacement of
driveway and apron shall be of the same material.
   (B)   The concrete and any supporting material shall conform with the
concrete specifications as listed in §
90.059 above. Concrete shall not be poured prior to inspection.
   (C)   The asphalt and any supporting material shall conform with the asphalt
specifications as listed in §
90.060 above. Asphalt shall not be poured prior to inspection.
   (D)   The brick pavers and any supporting material shall conform with ASTM C
902 Standard Specification for Pedestrian and Light Traffic Paving Brick. Brick
pavers shall not be installed prior to inspection.
   (E)   Public sidewalk construction must follow §
90.015 above. Public sidewalks must be of plain concrete and separate of apron
and driveway.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006; Am. Ord. 2010-08-0303O, passed 8-10-
2010)
§ 90.063 CURB CUTS.
   (A)   No person shall cut, break or change the stoop or slope of any curb in
the city without the prior approval of the Director of Public Works.
   (B)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
section shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her building bond or bonds.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
EXCAVATIONS
§ 90.070 PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION AND FEE.
   (A)   No person shall make any opening, excavation or tunnel in any public
street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or other public place in the city without
first obtaining a permit therefor.
   (B)   Applications for such a permit shall be made to the City Clerk and
shall specify the intended location and purpose of the excavation.
   (C)   The City Clerk shall immediately notify the Director of Public Works
of the application for the permit.
   (D)   The fee for the permit is $100.
   (E)   The city may waive this fee upon written request provided that the
excavation is in the best interests of the City of Oak Forest.
(2000 Code, § 12.16.010) (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), 2001) Penalty, see §
90.999
§ 90.071 RESTORATION OF STREETS AND SURFACES; CASH DEPOSIT.
   (A)   Each applicant shall restore a street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or
other public place, and the surface thereof, to the condition that existed
before an opening, excavation or tunnel was made.
   (B)   The applicant shall do all necessary backfilling or cause the same to
be done.
   (C)   All backfilling shall be done with care and caution and only bank or
lake sand shall be used as backfill. After the backfilling has been properly
done, any material excavated or not used shall be removed from the location of
the excavation to the places as the Director of Public Works directs.
   (D)   In restoring the street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or other public
place, the city may use its own employees and equipment and make reasonable
charges therefor, or it may engage the services of other persons and equipment
and charge the cost thereof to the applicant.
   (E)   Applicants not restoring a street, alley, sidewalk, parkway or other
public place shall be liable for all restoration costs and shall be fined $100
per day from the date specified in written notice from the city.
(2000 Code, § 12.16.020) (Ord. 2506 § 2 (part), passed - -2001)
§ 90.072 SUPERVISION BY DIRECTOR OF PUBLIC WORKS.
   All openings, excavations, tunnels, refills and resurfacing in the city
shall be made under the supervision of the Director of Public Works.
(2000 Code, § 12.16.030) Penalty, see §
90.999
STREET AND SIDEWALK USE REGULATIONS
§ 90.085 SOLICITATION OF FUNDS BY CHARITABLE ORGANIZATIONS.
   (A)   All religious or charitable organizations seeking to solicit funds on
streets in the city must hereafter this date complete a permit application
available at City Hall or on the city's web site. This permit application must
be completed in its entirety, dated and signed by an officer of the religious
or charitable organization seeking to solicit funds in the city.
   (B)   Any religious or charitable organization seeking to solicit funds on
streets in the city must also provide a not-for-profit certificate issued by
the Attorney General of the State of Illinois, as well as a certificate of
insurance with an appropriate level of insurance as noted on the permit
application.
   (C)   The religious or charitable organization must submit the permit
application, not-for-profit certificate and certificate of insurance to the
Mayor or his or her designee. All solicitation on public roadways in the city
must comply with the following provisions:
      (1)   A soliciting person or agency shall be registered with the Illinois
Attorney General as a charitable organization, as provided by ILCS Ch. 225, Act
460, §§ 1 et seq., An Act to Regulate Solicitations and Collection of Funds for
Charitable Purposes. The soliciting person or agency must be engaged in
statewide fund raising activity and will be liable for any injuries to any
person or property during the solicitation which is causally related to an act
of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
      (2)   No person shall stand on a roadway for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except after receiving a fully
executed permit from the city.
      (3)   No religious or charitable organization will be given a permit to
solicit for more than two 12- hour periods on roadways in the city in any
calendar year (January - December).
      (4)   No more than one permit shall be issued by the city for the same
date at the same intersection. Applications will be treated on a first come,
first served basis.
      (5)   Solicitations shall only be conducted at traffic control
intersections when traffic has come to a full stop during the hours of
daylight, but in no event earlier than 7:00 a.m. in the morning or later than
7:00 p.m. in the evening.
      (6)   Any person engaged in the act of soliciting on a public roadway
shall be 16 years of age or more and wear a high visibility yellow or orange
safety vest and clear identification of the organization undertaking the
solicitation.
      (7)   Solicitors may only solicit an behalf of a permitted organization
and such solicitation may only occur during a charitable solicitation event.
      (8)   Solicitors shall not approach a moving vehicle or one that does not
have a window down and an occupant has given some sign of assent to approach.
      (9)   Solicitors shall only enter the roadway while the traffic signal
for that lane is red and shall not enter the roadway while traffic is moving.
      (10)   No solicitor shall at any time enter or remain in the traveled
portion of the roadway or solicit in a manner which impedes the flow of
traffic.
      (11)   No person shall solicit in the public right-of-way at any time or
place not designated in the application permit under which the person is
conducting the solicitation.
      (12)   Any violation of the provisions of this section or extraordinarily
adverse weather conditions will constitute a reason for the city to cease all
soliciting activities.
   (D)   The permit application, not-for-profit certificate and certificate of
insurance must be submitted to the Mayor's office at least 30 calendar days
before the requested date(s) of solicitation. The city will have seven calendar
days to either approve or reject the request for solicitation.
   (E)   The provisions of this application process will encourage religious
and charitable organizations to make their plans to solicit funds on roadways
in the city well in advance of their requested date(s). It will also allow
proper processing of requests by the municipality, afford an equal opportunity
to all those religious and charitable organizations that wish to solicit funds
in the city, and promote activities that result in the safer solicitation of
funds on crowded public roadways.
(2000 Code, § 12.20.020) (Am. Ord. 2011-09-0352O, passed 9-27-2011) Penalty,
see §
90.999
§ 90.086 ENCROACHMENTS ON ROUTE 50 (CICERO AVENUE).
   No person, firm, corporation or other entity shall install, place, maintain
or construct any structure that encroaches upon the state right-of-way on Route
50 (Cicero Avenue) within the limits of the city.
(2000 Code, § 12.20.030) Penalty, see §
90.999
TREES AND PARKWAYS
§ 90.100 PURPOSE.
   (A)   The purpose of this subchapter is to provide for the proper parkway
standards and establishment of new trees, the protection and maintenance of
existing trees and the timely removal of hazardous or infectious diseased trees
on both public and private property.
   (B)   It is further intended to balance the property rights of individual
property owners with those of the overall health, safety and welfare interests
of the city. Trees enhance and preserve the air quality of the city through the
filtering effect of trees on air pollutants, reduce noise within the city
through the baffle and barrier effect of trees on the spread of noise, reduce
topsoil erosion through the soil retention effect of tree roots, reduce energy
consumption through the wind break and shade effects, provide nesting areas for
birds and other wildlife which in turn assist in the control of insects, reduce
storm water runoff and the costs associated therewith, replenish ground water
supplies and protect and increase property values.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.101 RESIDENTIAL PARKWAY STANDARDS.
   All uses which require site plan or special use approval shall install and
maintain trees along any parkway which abuts the perimeter of the property.
   (A)   The parkway shall be grass or low ground cover, except where covered
by driveway pavement. A minimum of one parkway tree per 40 feet of frontage is
required for all development.
   (B)   The use of loose stone, rock, or gravel is prohibited on public
parkways.
   (C)   Other than trees, no landscaping shall be taller than two feet.
   (D)   No tree or bush with a mature height of more than two feet shall be
planted within a distance of 33 feet of any street corner, measured from the
point of the nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines as extended. No tree
shall be planted closer than six feet of any fire hydrant.
   (E)   Trees shall be planted on the center line of parkways or as close to
five feet from the sidewalk as possible and located so as not to interfere with
overhead wires or traffic or pedestrian safety.
   (F)   A minimum parkway width of four feet is required for trees in a
parkway.
   (G)   Wherever feasible, parkway trees shall be planted on the public
parkway and not on the private property side of the sidewalk.
   (H)   Parkway trees shall consist of shorter trees if overhead utilities
exist. Otherwise, taller trees are required as shown in the following list. No
species shall comprise more than 30% of the overall parkway tree count for new
development. A mixture of trees shall be planted whenever feasible.
   (I)   No person shall attach any object to a parkway tree.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.102 TREE REMOVAL PERMIT.
   No person shall remove or cut down any tree or shrub in any street, parkway
or other public place without first securing a permit from the Department of
Public Works. Any permit authorizing removal may be subject to such conditions
as the Director of Public Works or his or her designee may deem necessary or
appropriate to minimize damage to other trees or vegetation on a site, and may
include the installation of protective fencing.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.103 TREE DETERMINATION.
   The city shall designate a specified list of trees to be planted within the
city limits, only trees on this list have been approved. The Public Works
Director or his or her designee may from time to time allow deviation from this
list at his or her sole discretion.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)

(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.105 NUISANCE TREES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   The city, in accordance with the law, shall have the right to cause the
removal of any dead, diseased, or trees that are deemed a nuisance on private
property within the city, when such trees constitute a hazard to life and
property, or harbor insects or disease which constitutes a potential threat to
other trees within the city. The city will notify in writing the owners of such
trees. Removal is the responsibility of said owners and shall be done by the
owners at their own expense within 60 days after the date of service of notice
or such other time as may be agreed upon by the city and the property owner. In
the event of failure of owners to comply with such provisions, the city shall
have the authority to remove such trees and file a lien against the property
for the amount of the costs of removal.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.106 PRUNING, RIGHT-OF-WAY CLEARANCE OF PRIVATE TREES.
   Every owner of any privately owned tree overhanging any street or right-of-
way within the city shall prune the branches so that such branches shall not
obstruct the view of any street intersection and so that there shall be a clear
space of eight feet above the surface of the street or sidewalk. Said owners
shall remove all dead, diseased or dangerous privately owned trees, or broken
or decayed limbs which constitute a menace to the safety of the public. The
city, in accordance with the law, shall have the right to prune any tree or
shrub on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light
along the street from a street light or interferes with visibility of any
traffic control device or sign.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.107 VIOLATIONS OF TREE REGULATIONS.
   (A)   Whoever violates this subchapter, in addition to any other fines, or
fees, shall be subject to the following provisions:
      (1)   Fines: first offense, $500; second offense, $1,000; third and
subsequent offense, $2,500.
      (2)   All violations that are committed by the same person or any firm
controlled by such person shall be counted, regardless of whether or not the
violations occur at the same time. Any finding or plea of guilty or plea of "no
contest" upon a citation shall be deemed a violation.
   (B)   Any entity or person who injures a public tree shall be held
responsible for the costs of repairs, such as pruning or cabling, if the
injured tree will not die as a result of such injuries. In cases where the tree
has been damaged beyond repair and cannot remain in the public right-of-way,
the entity or person responsible for the damage shall remove the tree and stump
at their own costs, or if the tree is an immediate hazard, the entity or person
shall pay the cost the city incurs in its removal.
   (C)   In addition to any fines that may be assessed for violation of this
section, the person shall pay to the city a sum equal to the value or partial
value of the tree lost as a result of the violation. The value or partial value
of the tree lost shall be as determined by the Department of Public Works using
the most current edition of the Guide for Plant Appraisal prepared by the
Council of Tree and Landscape Appraisers, and edited, published and copyrighted
by the International Society of Arboriculture. Various factors used in the tree
value calculations for northern Illinois shall be obtained from the most
current edition of the Species Ratings and Appraisal Factors for Illinois
prepared by the Illinois Arborist Association. The collection of this fee shall
be used by the city for the replacement of the damaged or destroyed tree. Any
remaining funds after the damaged or destroyed tree has been replaced will be
deposited into a tree planting fund to be administered by the Director of
Public Works.
   (D)   If the entity or person cannot pay the fines and fees, a lien shall be
placed against the property.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
§ 90.108 INTERFERENCE WITH THE CITY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, delay or interfere with the
city or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the planting,
cultivating, mulching, pruning, spraying, or removing of any street trees, park
trees, or dead, nuisance, or diseased trees on private grounds.
(Ord. 2008-11-0207O, passed 11-25-2008)
HONORARY DESIGNATION OF STREETS
§ 90.120 REQUEST.
   (A)   Every request for the honorary designation of a street shall be
presented in writing to the City Clerk.
   (B)   All requests must include the following information:
      (1)   Name of the person, organization or entity to be honored;
      (2)   The humanitarian, civic, community or other reasons which make the
honor appropriate; and
      (3)   The name, address and phone number of the person submitting the
request.
   (C)   The request shall also be accompanied by either a petition signed by
occupants of at least 75 residential locations within the city or a memorandum
submitted by at least three aldermen or the Mayor.
(2000 Code, § 12.28.010) (Ord. 2632 § 1, passed --2002)
§ 90.121 PROCESS.
   After receipt and review of the application to determine compliance with the
request criteria the City Clerk shall forward the request to the City Council
for consideration and approval.
(2000 Code, § 12.28.020) (Ord. 2632, § 2, passed --2002)
§ 90.122 DURATION.
   (A)   If approved, the honorary designation shall be placed and maintained
until the end of the calendar year following approval.
   (B)   At the end of this time the honorary sign shall be removed and
delivered to the family of the honored party.
(2000 Code, § 12.28.030) (Ord. 2632 § 3, passed --2002)
§ 90.999 PENALTY.
   (A)   Any person violating any provision of this chapter for which no
specific penalty is provided shall be subject to §
10.99.
   (B)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
§§
90.001 through
90.003 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her building bond or bonds.
(2000 Code, § 12.04.040)
   (C)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of §§
90.015 through
90.026 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her building bond or bonds.
(2000 Code, § 12.08.140)
   (D)   Whoever violated or fails to comply with any of the provisions of §§
90.040 through
90.055 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her building bond or bonds.
(Ord. 2006-06-0038O, passed 6-27-2006)
   (E)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of §§
90.070 through
90.072 shall suffer the forfeiture of his or her building bond or bonds.
(2000 Code, § 12.16.040)
